globe.name: show
globe.desc: Whether to show the globe component.

globe.name: zlevel
globe.desc:
The layer in which the component is located.

zlevel is used to make layers with Canvas. Graphical elements with different zlevel values will be placed in different Canvases, which is a common optimization technique. We can put those frequently changed elements (like those with animations) to a separate zlevel. Notice that too many Canvases will increase memory cost, and should be used carefully on mobile phones to avoid the crash.

Canvases with bigger zlevel will be placed on Canvases with smaller zlevel.

Note: The layers of the components in echarts-gl need to be separated from the layers of the components in echarts. The same zlevel cannot be used for both WebGL and Canvas drawing at the same time.

globe.name: left
globe.desc:
Distance between component and the left side of the container.

left value can be instant pixel value like 20; it can also be a percentage value relative to container width like '20%'; and it can also be 'left', 'center', or 'right'.

If the left value is set to be 'left', 'center', or 'right', then the component will be aligned automatically based on position.

globe.name: top
globe.desc:
Distance between component and the top side of the container.

top value can be instant pixel value like 20; it can also be a percentage value relative to container width like '20%'; and it can also be 'top', 'middle', or 'bottom'.

If the left value is set to be 'top', 'middle', or 'bottom', then the component will be aligned automatically based on position.

globe.name: right
globe.desc:
Distance between component and the right side of the container.

right value can be instant pixel value like 20; it can also be a percentage value relative to container width like '20%'.

Adaptive by default.

globe.name: bottom
globe.desc:
Distance between component and the bottom side of the container.

bottom value can be instant pixel value like 20; it can also be a percentage value relative to container width like '20%'.

Adaptive by default.

globe.name: width
globe.desc: The width of the view of the component.

globe.name: height
globe.desc: The height of the view of the component.

globe.name: globeRadius
globe.desc: The radius of the globe. The unit is relative to the three-dimensional space, related to viewControl.distance.

globe.name: globeOuterRadius
globe.desc: The outer radius of the globe. This area between globeRadius and globeOuterRadius will be used to display 3D histograms, scatter plots, etc.

globe.name: environment
globe.desc:
Environment map. Support for solid colors, gradual colors, URL of panoramic texture. The default is 'auto', which is used as the environment texture when light.ambientCubemap.texture is configured. Otherwise, the environment texture is not displayed.

Example: 

// Configure as a panoramic texture
environment: 'asset/starfield.jpg'
// Configured as a solid black background
environment: '#000'
// Configured as a background with a vertical gradient
environment: new echarts.graphic.LinearGradient(0, 0, 0, 1, [{
  offset: 0, color: '#00aaff' // Sky color
}, {
  offset: 0.7, color: '#998866' // Ground color
}, {
  offset: 1, color: '#998866' // Ground color
}], false)

globe.name: baseTexture
globe.desc:
The texture of the globe. Support for the string of image paths, images object or Canvas objects.

It also supports to use an echarts example as a texture directly, in which case mouse actions on Earth will be linked to the echarts instance used on the texture.

Example: 

// Use the globe's texture image
baseTexture: 'asset/earth.jpg'

// Use the world map example of echarts as a texture.
var canvas = document.createElement('canvas');
var mapChart = echarts.init(canvas, null, {
    width: 4096, height: 2048
});
mapChart.setOption({
    series : [
        {
            type: 'map',
            map: 'world',
            // Draw full size echarts example
            top: 0, left: 0,
            right: 0, bottom: 0,
            boundingCoords: [[-180, 90], [180, -90]]
        }
    ]
});
...
baseTexture: mapChart

globe.name: heightTexture
globe.desc: The high texture of the globe. High textures can be used to match Bump Map to show the light and dark details of the Earth's surface. The following two images show the difference between using heightTexture and not using heightTexuture.

globe.name: displacementTexture
globe.desc:
The displacement texture of the vertices of the globe, the default is the same as a heightTexture

Compared to bump maps, The displacement of the vertex is to directly shift the vertices according to the texture. Valid when displaymentScale is greater than 0.

globe.name: displacementScale
globe.desc: The displacement map of the globe's vertex. The default is 0, which means no displacement. The following two images show the effects of setting different displacementScale.

globe.name: displacementQuality
globe.desc: The quality of the globe's vertex displacement. Support for 'low', 'medium', 'high', 'ultra' settings.Higher quality can show more ground height detail. The following two images show the effects of different displacementQuality.

globe.name: shading
globe.desc:
The coloring effect of 3D graphics in 地球. The following three coloring methods are supported in echarts-gl:

  • 'color' Only display colors, not affected by other factors such as lighting.

  • 'lambert' Through the classic [lambert] coloring, can express the light and dark that the light shows.

  • 'realistic' Realistic rendering, combined with light.ambientCubemap and postEffect, can improve the quality and texture of the display. [Physical Based Rendering (PBR)] (https://www.marmoset.co/posts/physically-based-rendering-and-you-can-too/) is used in ECharts GL to represent realistic materials.

Here are the differences between different coloring effects.

globe.name: realisticMaterial
globe.desc: The configuration item of the realistic material is valid when shading is 'realistic'.

globe.name: lambertMaterial
globe.desc: The configuration item of the lambert material is valid when shading is 'lambert'.

globe.name: colorMaterial
globe.desc: The color material related configuration item is valid when shading is 'color'.

globe.name: light
globe.desc:
Light related settings. Invalid when shading is 'color'.

The lighting settings affect the components and all the charts on the component's coordinate system.

A reasonable lighting setting can make the brightness and darkness of the whole scene richer and more layered.

globe.name: postEffect
globe.desc:
Post-processing effects related configuration. It can add effects such as highlights, depth of field, screen space ambient occlusion (SSAO), toning to the picture. And it can make the whole picture more textured.

The following are the differences between closing postEffect and opening postEffect.

Note that when postEffect is enable, temporalSuperSampling is enable by default. After the picture is still, the picture will continue to be enhanced, including anti-aliasing, depth of field, SSAO, shadows, etc.

globe.name: temporalSuperSampling
globe.desc:
Temporal supersampling. After opening postEffect, WebGL's default MSAA (MultiSampling Anti-Aliasing) will not work, so we need to solve the problem of sampling.

Temporal supersampling is an anti-aliasing method. After the picture is still, it will continue to sample multiple times and taken at several instances inside the pixel and an average color value is calculated, thus achieving anti-aliasing effect. And in this process, ECharts-gl also progressively enhances some of the effects in postEffect that require sampled guarantees. For example SSAO, Depth of Field, and shadow.

The following is the difference between not opening temporalSuperSampling and opening temporalSuperSampling.

globe.name: viewControl
globe.desc: viewControl is used for mouse rotation, zooming, and other perspective control.

globe.name: layers
globe.desc: Configuration of the Earth's Surface Layer. You can use this configuration item to add clouds, or to supplement baseTexture to draw the outline of the country, and so on.

globe.realisticMaterial.name: detailTexture
globe.realisticMaterial.desc: The texture map of the material detail.

globe.realisticMaterial.name: textureTiling
globe.realisticMaterial.desc:
Tiles the texture map of the material detail. The default is 1, which means that the stretch is filled. When greater than 1, the number indicates how many times the texture is tiled.

Note: The use of tiling requires the detail texture height and width to be 2 to the power of n. For example, 512x512, if it is a 200x200 texture, you cannot use tiling.

globe.realisticMaterial.name: textureOffset
globe.realisticMaterial.desc: The displacement of the texture detail texture.

globe.realisticMaterial.name: roughness
globe.realisticMaterial.desc:
The roughness attribute is used to indicate the roughness of the material, 0 is completely smooth, 1 is completely rough, and the middle value is between the two.

The following images show the effect of roughness in globe](~globe)0.2(smooth) and0.8` (rough).

When you want to express more complex materials. You can set roughness directly to the texture that stores the roughness with each pixel as follows.

The more white the color in the texture, the larger the value and the rougher it is. You can get texture resources of different materials from resource websites such as [http://freepbr.com/] (http://freepbr.com/). You can also generate it yourself using other tools.

globe.realisticMaterial.name: metalness
globe.realisticMaterial.desc:
The metalness attribute is used to indicate whether the material is metal or non-metal, 0 is non-metallic, 1 is metal, and the middle value is between the two. Usually set to 0 and 1 to meet most of the scenes.

The picture below show the difference between `metal' and '0' in globe.

As with roughness you can set metalness directly to the metal texture.

globe.realisticMaterial.name: roughnessAdjust
globe.realisticMaterial.desc: Roughness adjustment is useful when using roughness map. The overall roughness of the texture can be adjusted. The default is 0.5, 0 is completely smooth, 1 is completely rough.

globe.realisticMaterial.name: metalnessAdjust
globe.realisticMaterial.desc: Metalness adjustment is useful when using metalness maps. The overall metallicity of the texture can be adjusted. The default is 0.5, 0 is non-metal, 1 is metal.

globe.realisticMaterial.name: normalTexture
globe.realisticMaterial.desc:
Normal map of material details.

Using normal maps, you can still display rich shades of detail on the surface of the object with fewer vertices.

globe.lambertMaterial.name: detailTexture
globe.lambertMaterial.desc: The texture map of the material detail.

globe.lambertMaterial.name: textureTiling
globe.lambertMaterial.desc:
Tiles the texture map of the material detail. The default is 1, which means that the stretch is filled. When greater than 1, the number indicates how many times the texture is tiled.

Note: The use of tiling requires the detail texture height and width to be 2 to the power of n. For example, 512x512, if it is a 200x200 texture, you cannot use tiling.

globe.lambertMaterial.name: textureOffset
globe.lambertMaterial.desc: The displacement of the texture detail texture.

globe.colorMaterial.name: detailTexture
globe.colorMaterial.desc: The texture map of the material detail.

globe.colorMaterial.name: textureTiling
globe.colorMaterial.desc:
Tiles the texture map of the material detail. The default is 1, which means that the stretch is filled. When greater than 1, the number indicates how many times the texture is tiled.

Note: The use of tiling requires the detail texture height and width to be 2 to the power of n. For example, 512x512, if it is a 200x200 texture, you cannot use tiling.

globe.colorMaterial.name: textureOffset
globe.colorMaterial.desc: The displacement of the texture detail texture.

globe.light.main.name: color
globe.light.main.desc: The color of the main light source.

globe.light.main.name: intensity
globe.light.main.desc: The intensity of the main light source.

globe.light.main.name: shadow
globe.light.main.desc:
Whether the main light source displays a shadow. The default is off.

Turning on the shadows can bring more realistic and layered lighting to the scene. But it also increases the operating overhead of the program.

The following two images show the difference between turning on the shadow and turning off the shadow.

globe.light.main.name: shadowQuality
globe.light.main.desc:
The quality of the shadow. You can choose 'low', 'medium', 'high', 'ultra'

The following two images shows the difference between low quality and high quality shadows.

globe.light.main.name: alpha
globe.light.main.desc:
The main light source is around the x-axis, which is the angle of up-down rotation. Control the direction of the light with beta.

As the following image show:

The globe component can control the time of sunlight by time.

globe.light.main.name: beta
globe.light.main.desc: The main light source is around the y-axis, which is the angle of the left-right rotation.

globe.light.main.name: time
globe.light.main.desc: The time of sunshine. The current system time is used by default.

globe.light.name: main
globe.light.desc: The setting of the main light source of the scene. In the globe component is the sun.

globe.light.name: ambientCubemap
globe.light.desc: The ambientCubemap uses texture as the source of ambient light, which provides diffuse and specular for objects. The diffuse and specular can be set separately by diffuseIntensity and specularIntensity.

globe.light.ambientCubemap.name: texture
globe.light.ambientCubemap.desc:
The URL of the ambient cubemap supports HDR images in the .hdr format. You can obtained the resources for .hdr from http://www.hdrlabs.com/sibl/archive.html and other websites.

Example：

ambientCubemap: {
    texture: 'pisa.hdr',
    // The exposure value used when analytic hdr
    exposure: 1.0
}

globe.postEffect.name: enable
globe.postEffect.desc: Whether to enable post-processing effects. Not enabled by default.

globe.postEffect.name: bloom
globe.postEffect.desc: Bloom is used to reproducing the effects that occur in real cameras when taking pictures in a bright environment. Because traditional RGB can only represent colors in the range of '0 - 255', so we need to use the bloom effect simulates fringes of light extending from the borders of bright areas, creating the illusion of a bright light overwhelming the camera. As shown below：

globe.postEffect.name: depthOfField
globe.postEffect.desc:
Depth of Field is a post-processing effect that simulates the focus properties of a camera. The area of focus is clear, and the area away from the focus is gradually blurred.

The depth of field effect allows the observer to focus on the area of focus and make the picture feel stronger. Large depth of field can also create a macro model effect.

The following are the differences between turning off and turning on the depth of field effect.

globe.postEffect.name: screenSpaceAmbientOcclusion
globe.postEffect.desc:
The ambient occlusion post-processing effect darkens the corners, holes, crevices, and areas where most light can`t reach. It is a supplement to the traditional shadow map, which makes the whole scene more natural and layered.

Below is a comparison of the effects of no SSAO and SSAO:

globe.postEffect.name: colorCorrection
globe.postEffect.desc:
Color correction and adjustment. Similar to Color Adjustments in Photoshop.

The same scene in the figure below is adjusted to the difference between the cool color system and the warm color system.

globe.postEffect.name: FXAA
globe.postEffect.desc:
After opening postEffect, WebGL's default MSAA (Multi Sampling Anti Aliasing) will not work. At this time, FXAA (Fast Approximate Anti-Aliasing) can solve the anti-aliasing problem quickly and easily. FXAA blurs the edge of the scene to solve the problem of aliasing. It works well on some scenes, but in echarts-gl, you need to ensure that the edges of many texts and lines are sharp and clear, so FXAA is not suitable. At this point we can use supersampling by setting a higher devicePixelRatio as follows:

var chart = echarts.init(dom, null, {
    devicePixelRatio: 2
})

However, setting a higher devicePixelRatio has high requirements for computer performance, so more often we recommend using temporalSuperSampling in echarts-gl. After the picture is still, it will continue to sample multiple times and taken at several instances inside the pixel and an average color value is calculated.,thus achieving anti-aliasing effect.

globe.postEffect.bloom.name: bloomIntensity
globe.postEffect.bloom.desc: The intensity of the bloom. The default is 0.1.

globe.postEffect.depthOfField.name: enable
globe.postEffect.depthOfField.desc: Whether to enable the depth of field.

globe.postEffect.depthOfField.name: focalDistance
globe.postEffect.depthOfField.desc: The initial focus distance. The user can click on the area to automatically focus.

globe.postEffect.depthOfField.name: focalRange
globe.postEffect.depthOfField.desc: The size of the in-focus area. The objects in this range are completely clear and there is no blurring.

globe.postEffect.depthOfField.name: fstop
globe.postEffect.depthOfField.desc: [F value] of the lens (https://zh.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E7%84%A6%E6%AF%94), the smaller the value, the shallower the depth of field.

globe.postEffect.depthOfField.name: blurRadius
globe.postEffect.depthOfField.desc:
Blur radius outside the focus.

The difference blur effect between the different radius.

globe.postEffect.SSAO.name: enable
globe.postEffect.SSAO.desc: Whether to enable SSAO (screen space ambient occlusion). Not enabled by default.

globe.postEffect.SSAO.name: quality
globe.postEffect.SSAO.desc: The quality of SSAO (screen space ambient occlusion). Supporting'low', 'medium', 'high', 'ultra'

globe.postEffect.SSAO.name: radius
globe.postEffect.SSAO.desc:
The radius of the SSAO (screen space ambient occlusion). The larger the radius, the more natural the effect, but you need to set a higher 'quality'.

The following example is the difference between a smaller and larger radius:

globe.postEffect.SSAO.name: intensity
globe.postEffect.SSAO.desc: The intensity of SSAO (screen space ambient occlusion). The larger the value, the darker the color.

globe.postEffect.colorCorrection.name: lookupTexture
globe.postEffect.colorCorrection.desc:
Color correction lookup texture, recommended.

The color correction lookup texture is a texture image like the one below.

This is the basic lookup texture image that you can use directly. To adjust the color of the scene to the effect you want, you can take a screenshot of the scene and adjust the color to the desired effect in image processing software such as Photoshop. Then apply the same adjustment to the image of the lookup texture above.

For example, after turning into a cool tone, the image of the lookup texture will look like this:

Then the texture image is used as the value of the configuration item, and you can get the same effect in Photoshop.

Of course, if you just want to get a screenshot, you don't have to do it anymore, but if you want to easily adjust to the ideal color in real-time interactive works, this is very useful.

globe.postEffect.FXAA.name: enable
globe.postEffect.FXAA.desc: Whether to enable FXAA. Not enabled by default.

globe.temporalSuperSampling.name: enable
globe.temporalSuperSampling.desc: Whether to enable temporal supersampling. By default, temporal supersampling is also turned on synchronously when [postEffect] (~globe.postEffect) is turned on.

globe.viewControl.name: projection
globe.viewControl.desc: The way of projection, the default is 'perspective' projection, also supports setting to 'orthogonal' projection.

globe.viewControl.name: autoRotate
globe.viewControl.desc: Whether to enable the angle of view to automatically rotate around the object.

globe.viewControl.name: autoRotateDirection
globe.viewControl.desc: The direction in which the object auto rotates. The default is 'cw' means clockwise from top to bottom, and can also use 'ccw' means counterclockwise from top to bottom.

globe.viewControl.name: autoRotateSpeed
globe.viewControl.desc: The speed at which the object auto rotates. The unit is angle/second, the default is 10, which is a turn of 36 seconds.

globe.viewControl.name: autoRotateAfterStill
globe.viewControl.desc: The time interval for automatic rotation to resume after the mouse is still. Valid after opening autoRotate.

globe.viewControl.name: damping
globe.viewControl.desc: The damping when the mouse is rotated, zoomed, etc. When it is greater than 0, the angle of view will continue to move (rotate and zoom) due to certain inertia after the mouse is still.

globe.viewControl.name: rotateSensitivity
globe.viewControl.desc:
The sensitivity of the rotation operation. The greater the value, the more sensitive. Supports the use of arrays to set the horizontal and vertical rotation sensitivity separately.

The default is 1.

Cannot be rotated after setting to 0.

// can't rotate
rotateSensitivity: 0
// can only be rotated horizontally
rotateSensitivity: [1, 0]
//  can only rotate vertically
rotateSensitivity: [0, 1]

globe.viewControl.name: zoomSensitivity
globe.viewControl.desc:
The sensitivity of the zoom operation, the larger the value, the more sensitive. The default is 1.

Cant be scaled after setting to0`.

globe.viewControl.name: panSensitivity
globe.viewControl.desc:
The sensitivity of the panning operation, the greater the value, the more sensitive. Supports the use of arrays to set the horizontal and vertical translation sensitivity.

The default is 1.

Cannot pan after setting to 0.

globe.viewControl.name: panMouseButton
globe.viewControl.desc:
The mouse button used for panning operation supports:

  • 'left' left mouse button (default)

  • 'middle' middle mouse button

  • 'right' right mouse button

Note: If set to the right mouse button, the default context menu will be blocked.

globe.viewControl.name: rotateMouseButton
globe.viewControl.desc:
The mouse button used for the rotation operation supports:

  • 'left' left mouse button

  • 'middle' middle mouse button (default)

  • 'right' right mouse button

Note: If set to the right mouse button, the default context menu will be blocked.

globe.viewControl.name: distance
globe.viewControl.desc: The distance of the default perspective from the subject. For globe, the distance from the Earth's surface is the distance from the center origin for other components such as grid3D and geo3D. Valid when projection is 'perspective'.

globe.viewControl.name: minDistance
globe.viewControl.desc: The angle of view is controlled by the mouse to bring the minimum distance to the subject. Valid when projection is 'perspective'.

globe.viewControl.name: maxDistance
globe.viewControl.desc: The angle of view can be extended to the maximum distance of the subject by mouse control. Valid when projection is 'perspective'.

globe.viewControl.name: orthographicSize
globe.viewControl.desc: The size of the orthogonal projection. Valid when projection is 'orthographic'.

globe.viewControl.name: maxOrthographicSize
globe.viewControl.desc: The maximum value of the orthogonal projection scaling. Valid when projection is 'orthographic'.

globe.viewControl.name: minOrthographicSize
globe.viewControl.desc: The minimum value of the orthogonal projection scaling. Valid when projection is 'orthographic'

globe.viewControl.name: alpha
globe.viewControl.desc:
The angle of view is around the x-axis, which is the angle of rotation up and down. With beta you can control the direction of the perspective.

As shown below：

globe.viewControl.name: beta
globe.viewControl.desc: The angle of view is around the y-axis, which is the angle of rotation from left to right.

globe.viewControl.name: center
globe.viewControl.desc: At the center of the angle of view, the rotation will also rotate around this center point. The default is [0,0,0].

globe.viewControl.name: minAlpha
globe.viewControl.desc: The minimum alpha value to rotate up and down. That is, the angle of view can be rotated to reach the uppermost angle.

globe.viewControl.name: maxAlpha
globe.viewControl.desc: The maximum alpha value to rotate up and down. That is, the angle of view can be rotated to the lowest angle.

globe.viewControl.name: minBeta
globe.viewControl.desc: The minimum beta value to rotate left and right. That is, the angle of view can be rotated to the leftmost angle.

globe.viewControl.name: maxBeta
globe.viewControl.desc: The maximum beta value to rotate left and right rotation. That is, the angle of view can be rotated to the rightmost angle.

globe.viewControl.name: animation
globe.viewControl.desc: Whether to enable animation.

globe.viewControl.name: animationDurationUpdate
globe.viewControl.desc: The duration time for update the transition animation.

globe.viewControl.name: animationEasingUpdate
globe.viewControl.desc: The easing effect for update transition animation.

globe.viewControl.name: targetCoord
globe.viewControl.desc:
Position the longitudes and latitudes. Ignore alpha 和 beta after the setting.

viewControl: {
    // locate in BeiJing
    targetCoord: [116.46, 39.92]
}

globe.layers.name: type
globe.layers.desc:
Layper type, Optional：

  • 'overlay'

The overlay on the ground surface can be used to display clouds and the like.

  • 'blend'

Mix with baseTexture.

globe.layers.name: name
globe.layers.desc:
The name of the layer. When setting the properties of the layer with setOption, you can use the name to identify the layer that needs to be updated.

chart.setOption({
    globe: {
        layer: [{
            // Update the texture of the layer named 'cloud'
            name: 'cloud',
            texture: 'cloud.png'
        }]
    }
});

globe.layers.name: blendTo
globe.layers.desc:
When type is 'blend' is valid .

Optional：

  • albedo is mixed to albedo, affected by lighting.

  • emission is mixed to self-illuminating, unaffected by light.

globe.layers.name: shading
globe.layers.desc:
The coloring effect of the overlay is the same as globe.shading, which supports 'color', 'lambert', 'realistic'

Valid when type is 'overlay'.

globe.layers.name: distance
globe.layers.desc:
The distance from the overlay to the surface of the globe.

Valid when type is 'overlay'.

globe.layers.name: texture
globe.layers.desc:
The texture of the globe. Support for the string of image paths, images object or Canvas objects.

It also supports to use an echarts example as a texture directly, in which case mouse actions on Earth will be linked to the echarts instance used on the texture.

geo3D.name: show
geo3D.desc: Whether to display 3D geographic coordinate system components.

geo3D.name: map
geo3D.desc:
The map type. The map type used in ECharts-gl is the same as the geo component.

You can download the required map file in the Map Download Interface, then to import and register it into ECharts.

EChart provides map data in two formats. One is the JS file that can be imported directly through the script tag. After it is introduced, the map name and data will be automatically registered. Another is the JSON file that needs to be registered manually after loaded asynchronously by AJAX.

Here are two types of use examples:

JavaScript Introduction Example 

<script src="echarts.js"></script>
<script src="map/js/china.js"></script>
<script>
var chart = echarts.init(document.getElementById('main'));
chart.setOption({
    series: [{
        type: 'map',
        map: 'china'
    }]
});
</script>

JSON Introduction Example 

$.get('map/json/china.json', function (chinaJson) {
    echarts.registerMap('china', chinaJson);
    var chart = echarts.init(document.getElementById('main'));
    chart.setOption({
        series: [{
            type: 'map',
            map: 'china'
        }]
    });
});

ECharts uses the data in [geoJSON] (http://geojson.org/) format as the outline of the map. In addition, you can also obtain data in [geoJSON] (http://geojson.org/) format of the map by other means and register it in ECharts.

geo3D.name: boxWidth
geo3D.desc:
A 3D geographic coordinate system component width in a 3D scene. With viewControl.distance you can get the most appropriate display size.

The following image is a schematic diagram of boxWidth, boxHeight, boxDepth, regionHeight in A 3D geographic coordinate system component.

geo3D.name: boxHeight
geo3D.desc:
A 3D geographic coordinate system component height in a 3D scene.

Component height. This height contains the height of the bar and scatter on a 3D map.

geo3D.name: boxDepth
geo3D.desc:
A 3D geographic coordinate system component depth in a 3D scene.

The component depth defaults to automatic, ensuring that the scale of the 3D component is the same as the ratio of the input GeoJSON.

geo3D.name: regionHeight
geo3D.desc: The height of each area of the 3D map. This height is the height of the model, less than boxHeight. boxHeight - regionHeight will be used for the display of 3D bar, 3D scatter, and etc.

geo3D.name: environment
geo3D.desc:
Environment map. Support for solid colors, gradual colors, URL of panoramic texture. The default is 'auto', which is used as the environment texture when light.ambientCubemap.texture is configured. Otherwise, the environment texture is not displayed.

Example: 

// Configure as a panoramic texture
environment: 'asset/starfield.jpg'
// Configured as a solid black background
environment: '#000'
// Configured as a background with a vertical gradient
environment: new echarts.graphic.LinearGradient(0, 0, 0, 1, [{
  offset: 0, color: '#00aaff' // Sky color
}, {
  offset: 0.7, color: '#998866' // Ground color
}, {
  offset: 1, color: '#998866' // Ground color
}], false)

geo3D.name: groundPlane
geo3D.desc:
The ground allows the entire assembly to be “placed” to make the entire scene look more realistic.

groundPlane supports setting up separate realisticMaterial, colorMaterial, lambertMaterial and other materials. If not set, the material parameters of the component are taken by default.

geo3D.name: instancing
geo3D.desc: instancing will merge all the geometry in GeoJSON into one. When GeoJSON has a lot of (thousands) geometry, it can effectively improve drawing efficiency.

geo3D.name: label
geo3D.desc: The setting of the label.

geo3D.name: itemStyle
geo3D.desc: Visual properties of 3D graphics in A 3D geographic coordinate system component, including color, transparency, strokes, etc.

geo3D.name: emphasis
geo3D.desc: Graphic and label styles when mouse hover is highlighted.

geo3D.name: regions
geo3D.desc: The setting of the map area.

geo3D.name: shading
geo3D.desc:
The coloring effect of 3D graphics in A 3D geographic coordinate system component. The following three coloring methods are supported in echarts-gl:

  • 'color' Only display colors, not affected by other factors such as lighting.

  • 'lambert' Through the classic [lambert] coloring, can express the light and dark that the light shows.

  • 'realistic' Realistic rendering, combined with light.ambientCubemap and postEffect, can improve the quality and texture of the display. [Physical Based Rendering (PBR)] (https://www.marmoset.co/posts/physically-based-rendering-and-you-can-too/) is used in ECharts GL to represent realistic materials.

geo3D.name: realisticMaterial
geo3D.desc: The configuration item of the realistic material is valid when shading is 'realistic'.

geo3D.name: lambertMaterial
geo3D.desc: The configuration item of the lambert material is valid when shading is 'lambert'.

geo3D.name: colorMaterial
geo3D.desc: The color material related configuration item is valid when shading is 'color'.

geo3D.name: light
geo3D.desc:
Light related settings. Invalid when shading is 'color'.

The lighting settings affect the components and all the charts on the component's coordinate system.

A reasonable lighting setting can make the brightness and darkness of the whole scene richer and more layered.

geo3D.name: postEffect
geo3D.desc:
Post-processing effects related configuration. It can add effects such as highlights, depth of field, screen space ambient occlusion (SSAO), toning to the picture. And it can make the whole picture more textured.

The following are the differences between closing postEffect and opening postEffect.

Note that when postEffect is enable, temporalSuperSampling is enable by default. After the picture is still, the picture will continue to be enhanced, including anti-aliasing, depth of field, SSAO, shadows, etc.

geo3D.name: temporalSuperSampling
geo3D.desc:
Temporal supersampling. After opening postEffect, WebGL's default MSAA (MultiSampling Anti-Aliasing) will not work, so we need to solve the problem of sampling.

Temporal supersampling is an anti-aliasing method. After the picture is still, it will continue to sample multiple times and taken at several instances inside the pixel and an average color value is calculated, thus achieving anti-aliasing effect. And in this process, ECharts-gl also progressively enhances some of the effects in postEffect that require sampled guarantees. For example SSAO, Depth of Field, and shadow.

The following is the difference between not opening temporalSuperSampling and opening temporalSuperSampling.

geo3D.name: viewControl
geo3D.desc: viewControl is used for mouse rotation, zooming, and other perspective control.

geo3D.name: zlevel
geo3D.desc:
The layer in which the component is located.

zlevel is used to make layers with Canvas. Graphical elements with different zlevel values will be placed in different Canvases, which is a common optimization technique. We can put those frequently changed elements (like those with animations) to a separate zlevel. Notice that too many Canvases will increase memory cost, and should be used carefully on mobile phones to avoid the crash.

Canvases with bigger zlevel will be placed on Canvases with smaller zlevel.

Note: The layers of the components in echarts-gl need to be separated from the layers of the components in echarts. The same zlevel cannot be used for both WebGL and Canvas drawing at the same time.

geo3D.name: left
geo3D.desc:
Distance between component and the left side of the container.

left value can be instant pixel value like 20; it can also be a percentage value relative to container width like '20%'; and it can also be 'left', 'center', or 'right'.

If the left value is set to be 'left', 'center', or 'right', then the component will be aligned automatically based on position.

geo3D.name: top
geo3D.desc:
Distance between component and the top side of the container.

top value can be instant pixel value like 20; it can also be a percentage value relative to container width like '20%'; and it can also be 'top', 'middle', or 'bottom'.

If the left value is set to be 'top', 'middle', or 'bottom', then the component will be aligned automatically based on position.

geo3D.name: right
geo3D.desc:
Distance between component and the right side of the container.

right value can be instant pixel value like 20; it can also be a percentage value relative to container width like '20%'.

Adaptive by default.

geo3D.name: bottom
geo3D.desc:
Distance between component and the bottom side of the container.

bottom value can be instant pixel value like 20; it can also be a percentage value relative to container width like '20%'.

Adaptive by default.

geo3D.name: width
geo3D.desc: The width of the view of the component.

geo3D.name: height
geo3D.desc: The height of the view of the component.

geo3D.label.name: distance
geo3D.label.desc:
Distance to the host graphic element.

The distance from the label to the graphic. In a 3D Scatter, this distance is the pixel value of the screen space. In other figures, this distance is the relative 3D distance.

geo3D.label.name: formatter
geo3D.label.desc:
The formatter of the label content, which supports the string template and the callback function. In either form, \n is supported to represent a new line.

String template:

The model variation includes:

  • {a}: series name.
  • {b}: the name of a data item.
  • {c}: the value of a data item.

Example:

formatter: '{b}: {c}'

Callback function: Callback function is in form of:

(params: Object|Array) => string

The params is the single data set needed by formatter, which is formed as:

{
    componentType: 'series',
    // Series type
    seriesType: string,
    // Series index in option.series
    seriesIndex: number,
    // Series name
    seriesName: string,
    // Data name, or category name
    name: string,
    // Data index in input data array
    dataIndex: number,
    // Original data as input
    data: Object,
    // Value of data. In most series it is the same as data.
    // But in some series it is some part of the data (e.g., in map, radar)
    value: number|Array|Object,
    // encoding info of coordinate system
    // Key: coord, like ('x' 'y' 'radius' 'angle')
    // value: Must be an array, not null/undefined. Contain dimension indices, like:
    // {
    //     x: [2] // values on dimension index 2 are mapped to x axis.
    //     y: [0] // values on dimension index 0 are mapped to y axis.
    // }
    encode: Object,
    // dimension names list
    dimensionNames: Array<String>,
    // data dimension index, for example 0 or 1 or 2 ...
    // Only work in `radar` series.
    dimensionIndex: number,
    // Color of data
    color: string,

}

Note: the usage of encode and dimensionNames can be:

If data is:

dataset: {
    source: [
        ['Matcha Latte', 43.3, 85.8, 93.7],
        ['Milk Tea', 83.1, 73.4, 55.1],
        ['Cheese Cocoa', 86.4, 65.2, 82.5],
        ['Walnut Brownie', 72.4, 53.9, 39.1]
    ]
}

We can get values that corresponding to y axis by:

params.value[params.encode.y[0]]

If data is:

dataset: {
    dimensions: ['product', '2015', '2016', '2017'],
    source: [
        {product: 'Matcha Latte', '2015': 43.3, '2016': 85.8, '2017': 93.7},
        {product: 'Milk Tea', '2015': 83.1, '2016': 73.4, '2017': 55.1},
        {product: 'Cheese Cocoa', '2015': 86.4, '2016': 65.2, '2017': 82.5},
        {product: 'Walnut Brownie', '2015': 72.4, '2016': 53.9, '2017': 39.1}
    ]
}

We can get values that corresponding to y axis by:

params.value[params.dimensionNames[params.encode.y[0]]]

geo3D.label.textStyle.name: fontWeight
geo3D.label.textStyle.desc:
The font thick weight of the text.

Optional:

  • 'normal'
  • 'bold'
  • 'bolder'
  • 'lighter'
  • 100 | 200 | 300 | 400...

geo3D.itemStyle.name: color
geo3D.itemStyle.desc:
The color of the graphic. 

// pure white
[1, 1, 1, 1]

When using an array representation, each channel can set a value greater than 1 to represent the color value of HDR.

geo3D.itemStyle.name: borderWidth
geo3D.itemStyle.desc: The width of the border. With the border, you can distinguish each area more clearly. As shown below:

geo3D.realisticMaterial.name: detailTexture
geo3D.realisticMaterial.desc: The texture map of the material detail.

geo3D.realisticMaterial.name: textureTiling
geo3D.realisticMaterial.desc:
Tiles the texture map of the material detail. The default is 1, which means that the stretch is filled. When greater than 1, the number indicates how many times the texture is tiled.

Note: The use of tiling requires the detail texture height and width to be 2 to the power of n. For example, 512x512, if it is a 200x200 texture, you cannot use tiling.

geo3D.realisticMaterial.name: textureOffset
geo3D.realisticMaterial.desc: The displacement of the texture detail texture.

geo3D.realisticMaterial.name: roughness
geo3D.realisticMaterial.desc:
The roughness attribute is used to indicate the roughness of the material, 0 is completely smooth, 1 is completely rough, and the middle value is between the two.

The following images show the effect of roughness in globe](~globe)0.2(smooth) and0.8` (rough).

When you want to express more complex materials. You can set roughness directly to the texture that stores the roughness with each pixel as follows.

The more white the color in the texture, the larger the value and the rougher it is. You can get texture resources of different materials from resource websites such as [http://freepbr.com/] (http://freepbr.com/). You can also generate it yourself using other tools.

geo3D.realisticMaterial.name: metalness
geo3D.realisticMaterial.desc:
The metalness attribute is used to indicate whether the material is metal or non-metal, 0 is non-metallic, 1 is metal, and the middle value is between the two. Usually set to 0 and 1 to meet most of the scenes.

The picture below show the difference between `metal' and '0' in globe.

As with roughness you can set metalness directly to the metal texture.

geo3D.realisticMaterial.name: roughnessAdjust
geo3D.realisticMaterial.desc: Roughness adjustment is useful when using roughness map. The overall roughness of the texture can be adjusted. The default is 0.5, 0 is completely smooth, 1 is completely rough.

geo3D.realisticMaterial.name: metalnessAdjust
geo3D.realisticMaterial.desc: Metalness adjustment is useful when using metalness maps. The overall metallicity of the texture can be adjusted. The default is 0.5, 0 is non-metal, 1 is metal.

geo3D.realisticMaterial.name: normalTexture
geo3D.realisticMaterial.desc:
Normal map of material details.

Using normal maps, you can still display rich shades of detail on the surface of the object with fewer vertices.

geo3D.lambertMaterial.name: detailTexture
geo3D.lambertMaterial.desc: The texture map of the material detail.

geo3D.lambertMaterial.name: textureTiling
geo3D.lambertMaterial.desc:
Tiles the texture map of the material detail. The default is 1, which means that the stretch is filled. When greater than 1, the number indicates how many times the texture is tiled.

Note: The use of tiling requires the detail texture height and width to be 2 to the power of n. For example, 512x512, if it is a 200x200 texture, you cannot use tiling.

geo3D.lambertMaterial.name: textureOffset
geo3D.lambertMaterial.desc: The displacement of the texture detail texture.

geo3D.colorMaterial.name: detailTexture
geo3D.colorMaterial.desc: The texture map of the material detail.

geo3D.colorMaterial.name: textureTiling

geo3D.colorMaterial.name: textureOffset
geo3D.colorMaterial.desc: The displacement of the texture detail texture.

geo3D.light.main.name: color
geo3D.light.main.desc: The color of the main light source.

geo3D.light.main.name: intensity
geo3D.light.main.desc: The intensity of the main light source.

geo3D.light.main.name: shadow
geo3D.light.main.desc:
Whether the main light source displays a shadow. The default is off.

Turning on the shadows can bring more realistic and layered lighting to the scene. But it also increases the operating overhead of the program.

The following two images show the difference between turning on the shadow and turning off the shadow.

geo3D.light.main.name: shadowQuality
geo3D.light.main.desc:
The quality of the shadow. You can choose 'low', 'medium', 'high', 'ultra'

The following two images shows the difference between low quality and high quality shadows.

geo3D.light.main.name: alpha
geo3D.light.main.desc:
The main light source is around the x-axis, which is the angle of up-down rotation. Control the direction of the light with beta.

As the following image show:

The globe component can control the time of sunlight by time.

geo3D.light.main.name: beta
geo3D.light.main.desc: The main light source is around the y-axis, which is the angle of the left-right rotation.

geo3D.light.name: main
geo3D.light.desc: The setting of the main light source of the scene. In the globe component is the sun.

geo3D.light.name: ambientCubemap
geo3D.light.desc: The ambientCubemap uses texture as the source of ambient light, which provides diffuse and specular for objects. The diffuse and specular can be set separately by diffuseIntensity and specularIntensity.

geo3D.light.ambientCubemap.name: texture
geo3D.light.ambientCubemap.desc:
The URL of the ambient cubemap supports HDR images in the .hdr format. You can obtained the resources for .hdr from http://www.hdrlabs.com/sibl/archive.html and other websites.

Example：

ambientCubemap: {
    texture: 'pisa.hdr',
    // The exposure value used when analytic hdr
    exposure: 1.0
}

geo3D.postEffect.name: enable
geo3D.postEffect.desc: Whether to enable post-processing effects. Not enabled by default.

geo3D.postEffect.name: bloom
geo3D.postEffect.desc: Bloom is used to reproducing the effects that occur in real cameras when taking pictures in a bright environment. Because traditional RGB can only represent colors in the range of '0 - 255', so we need to use the bloom effect simulates fringes of light extending from the borders of bright areas, creating the illusion of a bright light overwhelming the camera. As shown below：

geo3D.postEffect.name: depthOfField
geo3D.postEffect.desc:
Depth of Field is a post-processing effect that simulates the focus properties of a camera. The area of focus is clear, and the area away from the focus is gradually blurred.

The depth of field effect allows the observer to focus on the area of focus and make the picture feel stronger. Large depth of field can also create a macro model effect.

The following are the differences between turning off and turning on the depth of field effect.

geo3D.postEffect.name: screenSpaceAmbientOcclusion
geo3D.postEffect.desc:
The ambient occlusion post-processing effect darkens the corners, holes, crevices, and areas where most light can`t reach. It is a supplement to the traditional shadow map, which makes the whole scene more natural and layered.

Below is a comparison of the effects of no SSAO and SSAO:

geo3D.postEffect.name: colorCorrection
geo3D.postEffect.desc:
Color correction and adjustment. Similar to Color Adjustments in Photoshop.

The same scene in the figure below is adjusted to the difference between the cool color system and the warm color system.

geo3D.postEffect.name: FXAA
geo3D.postEffect.desc:
After opening postEffect, WebGL's default MSAA (Multi Sampling Anti Aliasing) will not work. At this time, FXAA (Fast Approximate Anti-Aliasing) can solve the anti-aliasing problem quickly and easily. FXAA blurs the edge of the scene to solve the problem of aliasing. It works well on some scenes, but in echarts-gl, you need to ensure that the edges of many texts and lines are sharp and clear, so FXAA is not suitable. At this point we can use supersampling by setting a higher devicePixelRatio as follows:

var chart = echarts.init(dom, null, {
    devicePixelRatio: 2
})

However, setting a higher devicePixelRatio has high requirements for computer performance, so more often we recommend using temporalSuperSampling in echarts-gl. After the picture is still, it will continue to sample multiple times and taken at several instances inside the pixel and an average color value is calculated.,thus achieving anti-aliasing effect.

geo3D.postEffect.bloom.name: bloomIntensity
geo3D.postEffect.bloom.desc: The intensity of the bloom. The default is 0.1.

geo3D.postEffect.depthOfField.name: enable
geo3D.postEffect.depthOfField.desc: Whether to enable the depth of field.

geo3D.postEffect.depthOfField.name: focalDistance
geo3D.postEffect.depthOfField.desc: The initial focus distance. The user can click on the area to automatically focus.

geo3D.postEffect.depthOfField.name: focalRange
geo3D.postEffect.depthOfField.desc: The size of the in-focus area. The objects in this range are completely clear and there is no blurring.

geo3D.postEffect.depthOfField.name: fstop
geo3D.postEffect.depthOfField.desc: [F value] of the lens (https://zh.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E7%84%A6%E6%AF%94), the smaller the value, the shallower the depth of field.

geo3D.postEffect.depthOfField.name: blurRadius
geo3D.postEffect.depthOfField.desc:
Blur radius outside the focus.

The difference blur effect between the different radius.

geo3D.postEffect.SSAO.name: enable
geo3D.postEffect.SSAO.desc: Whether to enable SSAO (screen space ambient occlusion). Not enabled by default.

geo3D.postEffect.SSAO.name: quality
geo3D.postEffect.SSAO.desc: The quality of SSAO (screen space ambient occlusion). Supporting'low', 'medium', 'high', 'ultra'

geo3D.postEffect.SSAO.name: radius
geo3D.postEffect.SSAO.desc:
The radius of the SSAO (screen space ambient occlusion). The larger the radius, the more natural the effect, but you need to set a higher 'quality'.

The following example is the difference between a smaller and larger radius:

geo3D.postEffect.SSAO.name: intensity
geo3D.postEffect.SSAO.desc: The intensity of SSAO (screen space ambient occlusion). The larger the value, the darker the color.

geo3D.postEffect.colorCorrection.name: lookupTexture
geo3D.postEffect.colorCorrection.desc:
Color correction lookup texture, recommended.

The color correction lookup texture is a texture image like the one below.

This is the basic lookup texture image that you can use directly. To adjust the color of the scene to the effect you want, you can take a screenshot of the scene and adjust the color to the desired effect in image processing software such as Photoshop. Then apply the same adjustment to the image of the lookup texture above.

For example, after turning into a cool tone, the image of the lookup texture will look like this:

Then the texture image is used as the value of the configuration item, and you can get the same effect in Photoshop.

Of course, if you just want to get a screenshot, you don't have to do it anymore, but if you want to easily adjust to the ideal color in real-time interactive works, this is very useful.

geo3D.postEffect.FXAA.name: enable
geo3D.postEffect.FXAA.desc: Whether to enable FXAA. Not enabled by default.

geo3D.temporalSuperSampling.name: enable
geo3D.temporalSuperSampling.desc: Whether to enable temporal supersampling. By default, temporal supersampling is also turned on synchronously when [postEffect] (~geo3D.postEffect) is turned on.

geo3D.viewControl.name: projection
geo3D.viewControl.desc: The way of projection, the default is 'perspective' projection, also supports setting to 'orthogonal' projection.

geo3D.viewControl.name: autoRotate
geo3D.viewControl.desc: Whether to enable the angle of view to automatically rotate around the object.

geo3D.viewControl.name: autoRotateDirection
geo3D.viewControl.desc: The direction in which the object auto rotates. The default is 'cw' means clockwise from top to bottom, and can also use 'ccw' means counterclockwise from top to bottom.

geo3D.viewControl.name: autoRotateSpeed
geo3D.viewControl.desc: The speed at which the object auto rotates. The unit is angle/second, the default is 10, which is a turn of 36 seconds.

geo3D.viewControl.name: autoRotateAfterStill
geo3D.viewControl.desc: The time interval for automatic rotation to resume after the mouse is still. Valid after opening autoRotate.

geo3D.viewControl.name: damping
geo3D.viewControl.desc: The damping when the mouse is rotated, zoomed, etc. When it is greater than 0, the angle of view will continue to move (rotate and zoom) due to certain inertia after the mouse is still.

geo3D.viewControl.name: rotateSensitivity
geo3D.viewControl.desc:
The sensitivity of the rotation operation. The greater the value, the more sensitive. Supports the use of arrays to set the horizontal and vertical rotation sensitivity separately.

The default is 1.

Cannot be rotated after setting to 0.

// can't rotate
rotateSensitivity: 0
// can only be rotated horizontally
rotateSensitivity: [1, 0]
//  can only rotate vertically
rotateSensitivity: [0, 1]

geo3D.viewControl.name: zoomSensitivity
geo3D.viewControl.desc:
The sensitivity of the zoom operation, the larger the value, the more sensitive. The default is 1.

Cant be scaled after setting to0`.

geo3D.viewControl.name: panSensitivity
geo3D.viewControl.desc:
The sensitivity of the panning operation, the greater the value, the more sensitive. Supports the use of arrays to set the horizontal and vertical translation sensitivity.

The default is 1.

Cannot pan after setting to 0.

geo3D.viewControl.name: panMouseButton
geo3D.viewControl.desc:
The mouse button used for panning operation supports:

  • 'left' left mouse button (default)

  • 'middle' middle mouse button

  • 'right' right mouse button

Note: If set to the right mouse button, the default context menu will be blocked.

geo3D.viewControl.name: rotateMouseButton
geo3D.viewControl.desc:
The mouse button used for the rotation operation supports:

  • 'left' left mouse button

  • 'middle' middle mouse button (default)

  • 'right' right mouse button

Note: If set to the right mouse button, the default context menu will be blocked.

geo3D.viewControl.name: distance
geo3D.viewControl.desc: The distance of the default perspective from the subject. For globe, the distance from the Earth's surface is the distance from the center origin for other components such as grid3D and geo3D. Valid when projection is 'perspective'.

geo3D.viewControl.name: minDistance
geo3D.viewControl.desc: The angle of view is controlled by the mouse to bring the minimum distance to the subject. Valid when projection is 'perspective'.

geo3D.viewControl.name: maxDistance
geo3D.viewControl.desc: The angle of view can be extended to the maximum distance of the subject by mouse control. Valid when projection is 'perspective'.

geo3D.viewControl.name: orthographicSize
geo3D.viewControl.desc: The size of the orthogonal projection. Valid when projection is 'orthographic'.

geo3D.viewControl.name: maxOrthographicSize
geo3D.viewControl.desc: The maximum value of the orthogonal projection scaling. Valid when projection is 'orthographic'.

geo3D.viewControl.name: minOrthographicSize
geo3D.viewControl.desc: The minimum value of the orthogonal projection scaling. Valid when projection is 'orthographic'

geo3D.viewControl.name: alpha
geo3D.viewControl.desc:
The angle of view is around the x-axis, which is the angle of rotation up and down. With beta you can control the direction of the perspective.

As shown below：

geo3D.viewControl.name: beta
geo3D.viewControl.desc: The angle of view is around the y-axis, which is the angle of rotation from left to right.

geo3D.viewControl.name: center
geo3D.viewControl.desc: At the center of the angle of view, the rotation will also rotate around this center point. The default is [0,0,0].

geo3D.viewControl.name: minAlpha
geo3D.viewControl.desc: The minimum alpha value to rotate up and down. That is, the angle of view can be rotated to reach the uppermost angle.

geo3D.viewControl.name: maxAlpha
geo3D.viewControl.desc: The maximum alpha value to rotate up and down. That is, the angle of view can be rotated to the lowest angle.

geo3D.viewControl.name: minBeta
geo3D.viewControl.desc: The minimum beta value to rotate left and right. That is, the angle of view can be rotated to the leftmost angle.

geo3D.viewControl.name: maxBeta
geo3D.viewControl.desc: The maximum beta value to rotate left and right rotation. That is, the angle of view can be rotated to the rightmost angle.

geo3D.viewControl.name: animation
geo3D.viewControl.desc: Whether to enable animation.

geo3D.viewControl.name: animationDurationUpdate
geo3D.viewControl.desc: The duration time for update the transition animation.

geo3D.viewControl.name: animationEasingUpdate
geo3D.viewControl.desc: The easing effect for update transition animation.

mapbox3D.name: style
mapbox3D.desc: Sets the style of the Mapbox map. Same as https://www.mapbox.com/mapbox-gl-js/style-spec/.

mapbox3D.name: center
mapbox3D.desc:
Sets the longitude and latitude of the center of the map. Longitude and latitude are represented by arrays, for example:

mapbox3D: {
    center: [104.114129, 37.550339],
    zoom: 3
}

mapbox3D.name: zoom
mapbox3D.desc: Sets the zoom level of the map. See https://www.mapbox.com/mapbox-gl-js/style-spec/#root-zoom

mapbox3D.name: bearing
mapbox3D.desc: Sets the bearing angle of the map. See https://www.mapbox.com/mapbox-gl-js/style-spec/#root-bearing

mapbox3D.name: pitch
mapbox3D.desc: Sets the pitch angle of the map. The default is 0 means perpendicular to the surface of the map. The greater value is 60. See https://www.mapbox.com/mapbox-gl-js/style-spec/#root-pitch

mapbox3D.name: shading
mapbox3D.desc:
The coloring effect of 3D graphics in mapbox3D. The following three coloring methods are supported in echarts-gl:

  • 'color' Only display colors, not affected by other factors such as lighting.

  • 'lambert' Through the classic [lambert] coloring, can express the light and dark that the light shows.

  • 'realistic' Realistic rendering, combined with light.ambientCubemap and postEffect, can improve the quality and texture of the display. [Physical Based Rendering (PBR)] (https://www.marmoset.co/posts/physically-based-rendering-and-you-can-too/) is used in ECharts GL to represent realistic materials.

mapbox3D.name: realisticMaterial
mapbox3D.desc: The configuration item of the realistic material is valid when shading is 'realistic'.

mapbox3D.name: lambertMaterial
mapbox3D.desc: The configuration item of the lambert material is valid when shading is 'lambert'.

mapbox3D.name: colorMaterial
mapbox3D.desc: The color material related configuration item is valid when shading is 'color'.

mapbox3D.name: light
mapbox3D.desc:
Light related settings. Invalid when shading is 'color'.

The lighting settings affect the components and all the charts on the component's coordinate system.

A reasonable lighting setting can make the brightness and darkness of the whole scene richer and more layered.

mapbox3D.name: postEffect
mapbox3D.desc:
Post-processing effects related configuration. It can add effects such as highlights, depth of field, screen space ambient occlusion (SSAO), toning to the picture. And it can make the whole picture more textured.

The following are the differences between closing postEffect and opening postEffect.

Note that when postEffect is enable, temporalSuperSampling is enable by default. After the picture is still, the picture will continue to be enhanced, including anti-aliasing, depth of field, SSAO, shadows, etc.

mapbox3D.name: temporalSuperSampling
mapbox3D.desc:
Temporal supersampling. After opening postEffect, WebGL's default MSAA (MultiSampling Anti-Aliasing) will not work, so we need to solve the problem of sampling.

Temporal supersampling is an anti-aliasing method. After the picture is still, it will continue to sample multiple times and taken at several instances inside the pixel and an average color value is calculated, thus achieving anti-aliasing effect. And in this process, ECharts-gl also progressively enhances some of the effects in postEffect that require sampled guarantees. For example SSAO, Depth of Field, and shadow.

The following is the difference between not opening temporalSuperSampling and opening temporalSuperSampling.

mapbox3D.realisticMaterial.name: detailTexture
mapbox3D.realisticMaterial.desc: The texture map of the material detail.

mapbox3D.realisticMaterial.name: textureTiling
mapbox3D.realisticMaterial.desc:
Tiles the texture map of the material detail. The default is 1, which means that the stretch is filled. When greater than 1, the number indicates how many times the texture is tiled.

Note: The use of tiling requires the detail texture height and width to be 2 to the power of n. For example, 512x512, if it is a 200x200 texture, you cannot use tiling.

mapbox3D.realisticMaterial.name: textureOffset
mapbox3D.realisticMaterial.desc: The displacement of the texture detail texture.

mapbox3D.realisticMaterial.name: roughness
mapbox3D.realisticMaterial.desc:
The roughness attribute is used to indicate the roughness of the material, 0 is completely smooth, 1 is completely rough, and the middle value is between the two.

The following images show the effect of roughness in globe](~globe)0.2(smooth) and0.8` (rough).

When you want to express more complex materials. You can set roughness directly to the texture that stores the roughness with each pixel as follows.

The more white the color in the texture, the larger the value and the rougher it is. You can get texture resources of different materials from resource websites such as [http://freepbr.com/] (http://freepbr.com/). You can also generate it yourself using other tools.

mapbox3D.realisticMaterial.name: metalness
mapbox3D.realisticMaterial.desc:
The metalness attribute is used to indicate whether the material is metal or non-metal, 0 is non-metallic, 1 is metal, and the middle value is between the two. Usually set to 0 and 1 to meet most of the scenes.

The picture below show the difference between `metal' and '0' in globe.

As with roughness you can set metalness directly to the metal texture.

mapbox3D.realisticMaterial.name: roughnessAdjust
mapbox3D.realisticMaterial.desc: Roughness adjustment is useful when using roughness map. The overall roughness of the texture can be adjusted. The default is 0.5, 0 is completely smooth, 1 is completely rough.

mapbox3D.realisticMaterial.name: metalnessAdjust
mapbox3D.realisticMaterial.desc: Metalness adjustment is useful when using metalness maps. The overall metallicity of the texture can be adjusted. The default is 0.5, 0 is non-metal, 1 is metal.

mapbox3D.realisticMaterial.name: normalTexture
mapbox3D.realisticMaterial.desc:
Normal map of material details.

Using normal maps, you can still display rich shades of detail on the surface of the object with fewer vertices.

mapbox3D.lambertMaterial.name: detailTexture
mapbox3D.lambertMaterial.desc: The texture map of the material detail.

mapbox3D.lambertMaterial.name: textureTiling
mapbox3D.lambertMaterial.desc:
Tiles the texture map of the material detail. The default is 1, which means that the stretch is filled. When greater than 1, the number indicates how many times the texture is tiled.

Note: The use of tiling requires the detail texture height and width to be 2 to the power of n. For example, 512x512, if it is a 200x200 texture, you cannot use tiling.

mapbox3D.lambertMaterial.name: textureOffset
mapbox3D.lambertMaterial.desc: The displacement of the texture detail texture.

mapbox3D.colorMaterial.name: detailTexture
mapbox3D.colorMaterial.desc: The texture map of the material detail.

mapbox3D.colorMaterial.name: textureTiling
mapbox3D.colorMaterial.desc:
Tiles the texture map of the material detail. The default is 1, which means that the stretch is filled. When greater than 1, the number indicates how many times the texture is tiled.

Note: The use of tiling requires the detail texture height and width to be 2 to the power of n. For example, 512x512, if it is a 200x200 texture, you cannot use tiling.

mapbox3D.colorMaterial.name: textureOffset
mapbox3D.colorMaterial.desc: The displacement of the texture detail texture.

mapbox3D.light.main.name: color
mapbox3D.light.main.desc: The color of the main light source.

mapbox3D.light.main.name: intensity
mapbox3D.light.main.desc: The intensity of the main light source.

mapbox3D.light.main.name: shadow
mapbox3D.light.main.desc:
Whether the main light source displays a shadow. The default is off.

Turning on the shadows can bring more realistic and layered lighting to the scene. But it also increases the operating overhead of the program.

The following two images show the difference between turning on the shadow and turning off the shadow.

mapbox3D.light.main.name: shadowQuality
mapbox3D.light.main.desc:
The quality of the shadow. You can choose 'low', 'medium', 'high', 'ultra'

The following two images shows the difference between low quality and high quality shadows.

mapbox3D.light.main.name: alpha
mapbox3D.light.main.desc:
The main light source is around the x-axis, which is the angle of up-down rotation. Control the direction of the light with beta.

As the following image show:

The globe component can control the time of sunlight by time.

mapbox3D.light.main.name: beta
mapbox3D.light.main.desc: The main light source is around the y-axis, which is the angle of the left-right rotation.

mapbox3D.light.name: main
mapbox3D.light.desc: The setting of the main light source of the scene. In the globe component is the sun.

mapbox3D.light.name: ambientCubemap
mapbox3D.light.desc: The ambientCubemap uses texture as the source of ambient light, which provides diffuse and specular for objects. The diffuse and specular can be set separately by diffuseIntensity and specularIntensity.

mapbox3D.light.ambientCubemap.name: texture
mapbox3D.light.ambientCubemap.desc:
The URL of the ambient cubemap supports HDR images in the .hdr format. You can obtained the resources for .hdr from http://www.hdrlabs.com/sibl/archive.html and other websites.

Example：

ambientCubemap: {
    texture: 'pisa.hdr',
    // The exposure value used when analytic hdr
    exposure: 1.0
}

mapbox3D.postEffect.name: enable
mapbox3D.postEffect.desc: Whether to enable post-processing effects. Not enabled by default.

mapbox3D.postEffect.name: bloom
mapbox3D.postEffect.desc: Bloom is used to reproducing the effects that occur in real cameras when taking pictures in a bright environment. Because traditional RGB can only represent colors in the range of '0 - 255', so we need to use the bloom effect simulates fringes of light extending from the borders of bright areas, creating the illusion of a bright light overwhelming the camera. As shown below：

mapbox3D.postEffect.name: depthOfField
mapbox3D.postEffect.desc:
Depth of Field is a post-processing effect that simulates the focus properties of a camera. The area of focus is clear, and the area away from the focus is gradually blurred.

The depth of field effect allows the observer to focus on the area of focus and make the picture feel stronger. Large depth of field can also create a macro model effect.

The following are the differences between turning off and turning on the depth of field effect.

mapbox3D.postEffect.desc:
The ambient occlusion post-processing effect darkens the corners, holes, crevices, and areas where most light can`t reach. It is a supplement to the traditional shadow map, which makes the whole scene more natural and layered.

Below is a comparison of the effects of no SSAO and SSAO:

Color correction and adjustment. Similar to Color Adjustments in Photoshop.

mapbox3D.postEffect.bloom.name: bloomIntensity
mapbox3D.postEffect.bloom.desc: The intensity of the bloom. The default is 0.1.

mapbox3D.postEffect.depthOfField.name: enable
mapbox3D.postEffect.depthOfField.desc: Whether to enable the depth of field.

mapbox3D.postEffect.depthOfField.name: focalDistance
mapbox3D.postEffect.depthOfField.desc: The initial focus distance. The user can click on the area to automatically focus.

mapbox3D.postEffect.depthOfField.name: focalRange
mapbox3D.postEffect.depthOfField.desc: The size of the in-focus area. The objects in this range are completely clear and there is no blurring.

mapbox3D.postEffect.depthOfField.name: blurRadius
mapbox3D.postEffect.depthOfField.desc:
Blur radius outside the focus.

The difference blur effect between the different radius.

mapbox3D.postEffect.SSAO.name: enable
mapbox3D.postEffect.SSAO.desc: Whether to enable SSAO (screen space ambient occlusion). Not enabled by default.

mapbox3D.postEffect.SSAO.name: quality
mapbox3D.postEffect.SSAO.desc: The quality of SSAO (screen space ambient occlusion). Supporting'low', 'medium', 'high', 'ultra'

mapbox3D.postEffect.SSAO.name: radius
mapbox3D.postEffect.SSAO.desc:
The radius of the SSAO (screen space ambient occlusion). The larger the radius, the more natural the effect, but you need to set a higher 'quality'.

The following example is the difference between a smaller and larger radius:

mapbox3D.postEffect.SSAO.desc: The intensity of SSAO (screen space ambient occlusion). The larger the value, the darker the color.

mapbox3D.postEffect.colorCorrection.name: lookupTexture
mapbox3D.postEffect.colorCorrection.desc:
Color correction lookup texture, recommended.

The color correction lookup texture is a texture image like the one below.
