mapbox3D.postEffect.FXAA.name: enable
mapbox3D.postEffect.FXAA.desc: Whether to enable FXAA. Not enabled by default.

mapbox3D.temporalSuperSampling.name: enable
mapbox3D.temporalSuperSampling.desc: Whether to enable temporal supersampling. By default, temporal supersampling is also turned on synchronously when [postEffect] (~mapbox3D.postEffect) is turned on.

grid3D.name: show
grid3D.desc: Whether to display a 3D cartesian coordinate system component.

grid3D.name: boxWidth
grid3D.desc: 3D cartesian coordinate system width in a 3D scene. With viewControl.distance you can get the most appropriate display size.

grid3D.name: boxHeight
grid3D.desc: 3D cartesian coordinate system height in a 3D scene.

grid3D.name: boxDepth
grid3D.desc: 3D cartesian coordinate system depth in a 3D scene.

grid3D.name: axisLine
grid3D.desc: Settings related to axis line.

grid3D.name: axisLabel
grid3D.desc: Settings related to axis label.

grid3D.name: axisTick
grid3D.desc: Settings related to axis tick.

grid3D.name: splitLine
grid3D.desc: Settings related to axis line.

grid3D.name: splitArea
grid3D.desc: Split area of axis in grid area.

grid3D.name: axisPointer
grid3D.desc: Configurations for axis pointer.

grid3D.name: environment
grid3D.desc:
Environment map. Support for solid colors, gradual colors, URL of panoramic texture. The default is 'auto', which is used as the environment texture when light.ambientCubemap.texture is configured. Otherwise, the environment texture is not displayed.

Example: 

// Configure as a panoramic texture
environment: 'asset/starfield.jpg'
// Configured as a solid black background
environment: '#000'
// Configured as a background with a vertical gradient
environment: new echarts.graphic.LinearGradient(0, 0, 0, 1, [{
  offset: 0, color: '#00aaff' // Sky color
}, {
  offset: 0.7, color: '#998866' // Ground color
}, {
  offset: 1, color: '#998866' // Ground color
}], false)

grid3D.name: light
grid3D.desc:
Light related settings. Invalid when shading is 'color'.

The lighting settings affect the components and all the charts on the component's coordinate system.

A reasonable lighting setting can make the brightness and darkness of the whole scene richer and more layered.

grid3D.name: postEffect
grid3D.desc:
Post-processing effects related configuration. It can add effects such as highlights, depth of field, screen space ambient occlusion (SSAO), toning to the picture. And it can make the whole picture more textured.

The following are the differences between closing postEffect and opening postEffect.

Note that when postEffect is enable, temporalSuperSampling is enable by default. After the picture is still, the picture will continue to be enhanced, including anti-aliasing, depth of field, SSAO, shadows, etc.

grid3D.name: temporalSuperSampling
grid3D.desc:
Temporal supersampling. After opening postEffect, WebGL's default MSAA (MultiSampling Anti-Aliasing) will not work, so we need to solve the problem of sampling.

Temporal supersampling is an anti-aliasing method. After the picture is still, it will continue to sample multiple times and taken at several instances inside the pixel and an average color value is calculated, thus achieving anti-aliasing effect. And in this process, ECharts-gl also progressively enhances some of the effects in postEffect that require sampled guarantees. For example SSAO, Depth of Field, and shadow.

The following is the difference between not opening temporalSuperSampling and opening temporalSuperSampling.

grid3D.name: viewControl
grid3D.desc: viewControl is used for mouse rotation, zooming, and other perspective control.

grid3D.name: zlevel
grid3D.desc:
The layer in which the component is located.

zlevel is used to make layers with Canvas. Graphical elements with different zlevel values will be placed in different Canvases, which is a common optimization technique. We can put those frequently changed elements (like those with animations) to a separate zlevel. Notice that too many Canvases will increase memory cost, and should be used carefully on mobile phones to avoid the crash.

Canvases with bigger zlevel will be placed on Canvases with smaller zlevel.

Note: The layers of the components in echarts-gl need to be separated from the layers of the components in echarts. The same zlevel cannot be used for both WebGL and Canvas drawing at the same time.

grid3D.name: left
grid3D.desc:
Distance between component and the left side of the container.

left value can be instant pixel value like 20; it can also be a percentage value relative to container width like '20%'; and it can also be 'left', 'center', or 'right'.

If the left value is set to be 'left', 'center', or 'right', then the component will be aligned automatically based on position.

grid3D.name: top
grid3D.desc:
Distance between component and the top side of the container.

top value can be instant pixel value like 20; it can also be a percentage value relative to container width like '20%'; and it can also be 'top', 'middle', or 'bottom'.

If the left value is set to be 'top', 'middle', or 'bottom', then the component will be aligned automatically based on position.

grid3D.name: right
grid3D.desc:
Distance between component and the right side of the container.

right value can be instant pixel value like 20; it can also be a percentage value relative to container width like '20%'.

Adaptive by default.

grid3D.name: bottom
grid3D.desc:
Distance between component and the bottom side of the container.

bottom value can be instant pixel value like 20; it can also be a percentage value relative to container width like '20%'.

Adaptive by default.

grid3D.name: width
grid3D.desc: The width of the view of the component.

grid3D.name: height
grid3D.desc: The height of the view of the component.

grid3D.axisLine.name: show
grid3D.axisLine.desc: Set this to be false to prevent the axis line from showing.

grid3D.axisLine.name: interval
grid3D.axisLine.desc:
axis scale label is valid in the category axis.

By default, interval is automatically calculated to ensure a good display.

It can be set to 0 to force all labels to be displayed.

If the value is 1, it means "displays a label every other label". If the value is 2, it means "displays a label between two labels", and so on.

The interval data can be represented by a numerical value or by a callback function. The format of the callback function is as follows:

(index:number, value: string) => boolean

The first parameter is the index of the class, the second value is the name of the class, and if it is skipped, it returns false.

grid3D.axisLine.lineStyle.name: color
grid3D.axisLine.lineStyle.desc:
The color of the line.

In addition to color strings, RGBA values represented by arrays are supported, for example:

// pure white
[1, 1, 1, 1]

When using an array representation, each channel can set a value greater than 1 to represent the color value of HDR.

grid3D.axisLabel.name: show
grid3D.axisLabel.desc: Set this to be false to prevent the axis label from appearing.

grid3D.axisLabel.name: margin
grid3D.axisLabel.desc:
The margin between the axis label and the axis line.

Note： This distance is three-dimensional space, not screen space.

grid3D.axisLabel.name: interval
grid3D.axisLabel.desc:
axis scale label is valid in the category axis.

By default, interval is automatically calculated to ensure a good display.

It can be set to 0 to force all labels to be displayed.

If the value is 1, it means "displays a label every other label". If the value is 2, it means "displays a label between two labels", and so on.

The interval data can be represented by a numerical value or by a callback function. The format of the callback function is as follows:

(index:number, value: string) => boolean

The first parameter is the index of the class, the second value is the name of the class, and if it is skipped, it returns false.

grid3D.axisLabel.textStyle.name: color
grid3D.axisLabel.textStyle.desc:
Color of axis label is set to be axisLine.lineStyle.color by default. Callback function is supported, in the following format:

(val: string) => Color

Parameter is the text of label, and return value is the color. See the following example:

textStyle: {
    color: function (value, index) {
        return value >= 0 ? 'green' : 'red';
    }
}

grid3D.axisLabel.textStyle.name: fontWeight
grid3D.axisLabel.textStyle.desc:
The font thick weight of the text.

Optional:

  • 'normal'
  • 'bold'
  • 'bolder'
  • 'lighter'
  • 100 | 200 | 300 | 400...

grid3D.axisTick.name: show
grid3D.axisTick.desc: Set this to be false to prevent the axis tick from showing.

grid3D.axisTick.name: interval
grid3D.axisTick.desc:
axis scale label is valid in the category axis. Defaults to the same as axisLabel.interval.

By default, interval is automatically calculated to ensure a good display.

It can be set to 0 to force all labels to be displayed.

If the value is 1, it means "displays a label every other label". If the value is 2, it means "displays a label between two labels", and so on.

The interval data can be represented by a numerical value or by a callback function. The format of the callback function is as follows:

(index:number, value: string) => boolean

The first parameter is the index of the class, the second value is the name of the class, and if it is skipped, it returns false.

grid3D.axisTick.lineStyle.name: color
grid3D.axisTick.lineStyle.desc: Color of axis label is set to be axisLine.lineStyle.color by default.

grid3D.axisTick.lineStyle.name: width
grid3D.axisTick.lineStyle.desc: The width of the line.

grid3D.splitLine.name: show
grid3D.splitLine.desc: Set this to be false to prevent the axis line from showing.

grid3D.splitLine.name: interval
grid3D.splitLine.desc:
axis scale label is valid in the category axis.

By default, interval is automatically calculated to ensure a good display.

It can be set to 0 to force all labels to be displayed.

If the value is 1, it means "displays a label every other label". If the value is 2, it means "displays a label between two labels", and so on.

The interval data can be represented by a numerical value or by a callback function. The format of the callback function is as follows:

(index:number, value: string) => boolean

The first parameter is the index of the class, the second value is the name of the class, and if it is skipped, it returns false.

grid3D.splitLine.lineStyle.name: color
grid3D.splitLine.lineStyle.desc:
The color of the line.

In addition to color strings, RGBA values represented by arrays are supported, for example:

// pure white
[1, 1, 1, 1]

When using an array representation, each channel can set a value greater than 1 to represent the color value of HDR.

grid3D.splitArea.name: show
grid3D.splitArea.desc: Set this to be true to show the splitArea.

grid3D.splitArea.name: interval
grid3D.splitArea.desc:
Axis splitArea is valid in the category axis. Defaults to the same as axisLabel.interval.

By default, interval is automatically calculated to ensure a good display.

It can be set to 0 to force all labels to be displayed.

If the value is 1, it means "displays a label every other label". If the value is 2, it means "displays a label between two labels", and so on.

The interval data can be represented by a numerical value or by a callback function. The format of the callback function is as follows:

(index:number, value: string) => boolean

The first parameter is the index of the class, the second value is the name of the class, and if it is skipped, it returns false.

grid3D.splitArea.areaStyle.name: color
grid3D.splitArea.areaStyle.desc: Color of the split area. The split area color could also be set in color array, which the split lines would take as their colors in turns. Dark and light colors in turns are used by default.

grid3D.axisPointer.name: show
grid3D.axisPointer.desc: Whether to display the axisPointer. Set this to be true to show the splitArea.

grid3D.axisPointer.lineStyle.name: color
grid3D.axisPointer.lineStyle.desc:
The color of the line.

In addition to color strings, RGBA values represented by arrays are supported, for example:

// pure white
[1, 1, 1, 1]

When using an array representation, each channel can set a value greater than 1 to represent the color value of HDR.

grid3D.axisPointer.label.name: show
grid3D.axisPointer.label.desc: Whether to display the label of axisPointer. Value axes are displayed by default, while category axes are not.

grid3D.axisPointer.label.name: formatter
grid3D.axisPointer.label.desc:
The formatter of the label. . The first parameter to the function is the value of the current axis. The second parameter to the function is an array of values for all axes.

(value: number, valueAll: Array) => string

grid3D.axisPointer.label.name: margin
grid3D.axisPointer.label.desc: Distance between label and axis. Like the scale label, this distance is a 3D space rather than a screen pixel.

grid3D.axisPointer.label.textStyle.name: fontWeight
grid3D.axisPointer.label.textStyle.desc:
The font thick weight of the text.

Optional:

  • 'normal'
  • 'bold'
  • 'bolder'
  • 'lighter'
  • 100 | 200 | 300 | 400...

grid3D.light.main.name: color
grid3D.light.main.desc: The color of the main light source.

grid3D.light.main.name: intensity
grid3D.light.main.desc: The intensity of the main light source.

grid3D.light.main.name: shadow
grid3D.light.main.desc:
Whether the main light source displays a shadow. The default is off.

Turning on the shadows can bring more realistic and layered lighting to the scene. But it also increases the operating overhead of the program.

The following two images show the difference between turning on the shadow and turning off the shadow.

grid3D.light.main.name: shadowQuality
grid3D.light.main.desc:
The quality of the shadow. You can choose 'low', 'medium', 'high', 'ultra'

The following two images shows the difference between low quality and high quality shadows.

grid3D.light.main.name: alpha
grid3D.light.main.desc:
The main light source is around the x-axis, which is the angle of up-down rotation. Control the direction of the light with beta.

As the following image show:

The globe component can control the time of sunlight by time.

grid3D.light.main.name: beta
grid3D.light.main.desc: The main light source is around the y-axis, which is the angle of the left-right rotation.

grid3D.light.name: main
grid3D.light.desc: The setting of the main light source of the scene. In the globe component is the sun.

grid3D.light.name: ambientCubemap
grid3D.light.desc: The ambientCubemap uses texture as the source of ambient light, which provides diffuse and specular for objects. The diffuse and specular can be set separately by diffuseIntensity and specularIntensity.

grid3D.light.ambientCubemap.name: texture
grid3D.light.ambientCubemap.desc:
The URL of the ambient cubemap supports HDR images in the .hdr format. You can obtained the resources for .hdr from http://www.hdrlabs.com/sibl/archive.html and other websites.

Example：

ambientCubemap: {
    texture: 'pisa.hdr',
    // The exposure value used when analytic hdr
    exposure: 1.0
}

grid3D.postEffect.name: enable
grid3D.postEffect.desc: Whether to enable post-processing effects. Not enabled by default.

grid3D.postEffect.name: bloom
grid3D.postEffect.desc: Bloom is used to reproducing the effects that occur in real cameras when taking pictures in a bright environment. Because traditional RGB can only represent colors in the range of '0 - 255', so we need to use the bloom effect simulates fringes of light extending from the borders of bright areas, creating the illusion of a bright light overwhelming the camera. As shown below：

grid3D.postEffect.name: depthOfField
grid3D.postEffect.desc:
Depth of Field is a post-processing effect that simulates the focus properties of a camera. The area of focus is clear, and the area away from the focus is gradually blurred.

The depth of field effect allows the observer to focus on the area of focus and make the picture feel stronger. Large depth of field can also create a macro model effect.

The following are the differences between turning off and turning on the depth of field effect.

grid3D.postEffect.name: screenSpaceAmbientOcclusion
grid3D.postEffect.desc:
The ambient occlusion post-processing effect darkens the corners, holes, crevices, and areas where most light can`t reach. It is a supplement to the traditional shadow map, which makes the whole scene more natural and layered.

Below is a comparison of the effects of no SSAO and SSAO:

grid3D.postEffect.name: colorCorrection
grid3D.postEffect.desc:
Color correction and adjustment. Similar to Color Adjustments in Photoshop.

The same scene in the figure below is adjusted to the difference between the cool color system and the warm color system.

grid3D.postEffect.name: FXAA
grid3D.postEffect.desc:
After opening postEffect, WebGL's default MSAA (Multi Sampling Anti Aliasing) will not work. At this time, FXAA (Fast Approximate Anti-Aliasing) can solve the anti-aliasing problem quickly and easily. FXAA blurs the edge of the scene to solve the problem of aliasing. It works well on some scenes, but in echarts-gl, you need to ensure that the edges of many texts and lines are sharp and clear, so FXAA is not suitable. At this point we can use supersampling by setting a higher devicePixelRatio as follows:

var chart = echarts.init(dom, null, {
    devicePixelRatio: 2
})

However, setting a higher devicePixelRatio has high requirements for computer performance, so more often we recommend using temporalSuperSampling in echarts-gl. After the picture is still, it will continue to sample multiple times and taken at several instances inside the pixel and an average color value is calculated.,thus achieving anti-aliasing effect.

grid3D.postEffect.bloom.name: bloomIntensity
grid3D.postEffect.bloom.desc: The intensity of the bloom. The default is 0.1.

grid3D.postEffect.depthOfField.name: enable
grid3D.postEffect.depthOfField.desc: Whether to enable the depth of field.

grid3D.postEffect.depthOfField.name: focalDistance
grid3D.postEffect.depthOfField.desc: The initial focus distance. The user can click on the area to automatically focus.

grid3D.postEffect.depthOfField.name: focalRange
grid3D.postEffect.depthOfField.desc: The size of the in-focus area. The objects in this range are completely clear and there is no blurring.

grid3D.postEffect.depthOfField.name: fstop
grid3D.postEffect.depthOfField.desc: [F value] of the lens (https://zh.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E7%84%A6%E6%AF%94), the smaller the value, the shallower the depth of field.

grid3D.postEffect.depthOfField.name: blurRadius
grid3D.postEffect.depthOfField.desc:
Blur radius outside the focus.

The difference blur effect between the different radius.

grid3D.postEffect.SSAO.name: enable
grid3D.postEffect.SSAO.desc: Whether to enable SSAO (screen space ambient occlusion). Not enabled by default.

grid3D.postEffect.SSAO.name: quality
grid3D.postEffect.SSAO.desc: The quality of SSAO (screen space ambient occlusion). Supporting'low', 'medium', 'high', 'ultra'

grid3D.postEffect.SSAO.name: radius
grid3D.postEffect.SSAO.desc:
The radius of the SSAO (screen space ambient occlusion). The larger the radius, the more natural the effect, but you need to set a higher 'quality'.

The following example is the difference between a smaller and larger radius:

grid3D.postEffect.SSAO.name: intensity
grid3D.postEffect.SSAO.desc: The intensity of SSAO (screen space ambient occlusion). The larger the value, the darker the color.

grid3D.postEffect.colorCorrection.name: lookupTexture
grid3D.postEffect.colorCorrection.desc:
Color correction lookup texture, recommended.

The color correction lookup texture is a texture image like the one below.

This is the basic lookup texture image that you can use directly. To adjust the color of the scene to the effect you want, you can take a screenshot of the scene and adjust the color to the desired effect in image processing software such as Photoshop. Then apply the same adjustment to the image of the lookup texture above.

For example, after turning into a cool tone, the image of the lookup texture will look like this:

Then the texture image is used as the value of the configuration item, and you can get the same effect in Photoshop.

Of course, if you just want to get a screenshot, you don't have to do it anymore, but if you want to easily adjust to the ideal color in real-time interactive works, this is very useful.

grid3D.postEffect.FXAA.name: enable
grid3D.postEffect.FXAA.desc: Whether to enable FXAA. Not enabled by default.

grid3D.temporalSuperSampling.name: enable
grid3D.temporalSuperSampling.desc: Whether to enable temporal supersampling. By default, temporal supersampling is also turned on synchronously when [postEffect] (~grid3D.postEffect) is turned on.

grid3D.viewControl.name: projection
grid3D.viewControl.desc: The way of projection, the default is 'perspective' projection, also supports setting to 'orthogonal' projection.

grid3D.viewControl.name: autoRotate
grid3D.viewControl.desc: Whether to enable the angle of view to automatically rotate around the object.

grid3D.viewControl.name: autoRotateDirection
grid3D.viewControl.desc: The direction in which the object auto rotates. The default is 'cw' means clockwise from top to bottom, and can also use 'ccw' means counterclockwise from top to bottom.

grid3D.viewControl.name: autoRotateSpeed
grid3D.viewControl.desc: The speed at which the object auto rotates. The unit is angle/second, the default is 10, which is a turn of 36 seconds.

grid3D.viewControl.name: autoRotateAfterStill
grid3D.viewControl.desc: The time interval for automatic rotation to resume after the mouse is still. Valid after opening autoRotate.

grid3D.viewControl.name: damping
grid3D.viewControl.desc: The damping when the mouse is rotated, zoomed, etc. When it is greater than 0, the angle of view will continue to move (rotate and zoom) due to certain inertia after the mouse is still.

grid3D.viewControl.name: rotateSensitivity
grid3D.viewControl.desc:
The sensitivity of the rotation operation. The greater the value, the more sensitive. Supports the use of arrays to set the horizontal and vertical rotation sensitivity separately.

The default is 1.

Cannot be rotated after setting to 0.

// can't rotate
rotateSensitivity: 0
// can only be rotated horizontally
rotateSensitivity: [1, 0]
//  can only rotate vertically
rotateSensitivity: [0, 1]

grid3D.viewControl.name: zoomSensitivity
grid3D.viewControl.desc:
The sensitivity of the zoom operation, the larger the value, the more sensitive. The default is 1.

Cant be scaled after setting to0`.

grid3D.viewControl.name: panSensitivity
grid3D.viewControl.desc:
The sensitivity of the panning operation, the greater the value, the more sensitive. Supports the use of arrays to set the horizontal and vertical translation sensitivity.

The default is 1.

Cannot pan after setting to 0.

grid3D.viewControl.name: panMouseButton
grid3D.viewControl.desc:
The mouse button used for panning operation supports:

  • 'left' left mouse button (default)

  • 'middle' middle mouse button

  • 'right' right mouse button

Note: If set to the right mouse button, the default context menu will be blocked.

grid3D.viewControl.name: rotateMouseButton
grid3D.viewControl.desc:
The mouse button used for the rotation operation supports:

  • 'left' left mouse button

  • 'middle' middle mouse button (default)

  • 'right' right mouse button

Note: If set to the right mouse button, the default context menu will be blocked.

grid3D.viewControl.name: distance
grid3D.viewControl.desc: The distance of the default perspective from the subject. For globe, the distance from the Earth's surface is the distance from the center origin for other components such as grid3D and geo3D. Valid when projection is 'perspective'.

grid3D.viewControl.name: minDistance
grid3D.viewControl.desc: The angle of view is controlled by the mouse to bring the minimum distance to the subject. Valid when projection is 'perspective'.

grid3D.viewControl.name: maxDistance
grid3D.viewControl.desc: The angle of view can be extended to the maximum distance of the subject by mouse control. Valid when projection is 'perspective'.

grid3D.viewControl.name: orthographicSize
grid3D.viewControl.desc: The size of the orthogonal projection. Valid when projection is 'orthographic'.

grid3D.viewControl.name: maxOrthographicSize
grid3D.viewControl.desc: The maximum value of the orthogonal projection scaling. Valid when projection is 'orthographic'.

grid3D.viewControl.name: minOrthographicSize
grid3D.viewControl.desc: The minimum value of the orthogonal projection scaling. Valid when projection is 'orthographic'

grid3D.viewControl.name: alpha
grid3D.viewControl.desc:
The angle of view is around the x-axis, which is the angle of rotation up and down. With beta you can control the direction of the perspective.

As shown below：

grid3D.viewControl.name: beta
grid3D.viewControl.desc: The angle of view is around the y-axis, which is the angle of rotation from left to right.

grid3D.viewControl.name: center
grid3D.viewControl.desc: At the center of the angle of view, the rotation will also rotate around this center point. The default is [0,0,0].

grid3D.viewControl.name: minAlpha
grid3D.viewControl.desc: The minimum alpha value to rotate up and down. That is, the angle of view can be rotated to reach the uppermost angle.

grid3D.viewControl.name: maxAlpha
grid3D.viewControl.desc: The maximum alpha value to rotate up and down. That is, the angle of view can be rotated to the lowest angle.

grid3D.viewControl.name: minBeta
grid3D.viewControl.desc: The minimum beta value to rotate left and right. That is, the angle of view can be rotated to the leftmost angle.

grid3D.viewControl.name: maxBeta
grid3D.viewControl.desc: The maximum beta value to rotate left and right rotation. That is, the angle of view can be rotated to the rightmost angle.

grid3D.viewControl.name: animation
grid3D.viewControl.desc: Whether to enable animation.

grid3D.viewControl.name: animationDurationUpdate
grid3D.viewControl.desc: The duration time for update the transition animation.

grid3D.viewControl.name: animationEasingUpdate
grid3D.viewControl.desc: The easing effect for update transition animation.

xAxis3D.name: show
xAxis3D.desc: Whether to display the x-axis.

xAxis3D.name: name
xAxis3D.desc: The name of the axis.

xAxis3D.name: grid3DIndex
xAxis3D.desc: The index of the grid3D component used by the axis. The default is to use the first grid3D component.

xAxis3D.name: nameTextStyle
xAxis3D.desc: Text style of axis name.

xAxis3D.name: nameGap
xAxis3D.desc: The gap between the axis name and axis line. Note the distance is in 3D space, not the screen pixel value.

xAxis3D.name: type
xAxis3D.desc:
The type of the axis.

Optional:

  • 'value' The value axis. Suitable for continuous data.

  • 'category' The category axis. Suitable for the discrete category data. For this type, the category data must be set through data.

  • 'time' The timeline. Suitable for the continuous timing data. The time axis has a time format compared to the value axis, and the scale calculation is also different. For example, the scale of the month, week, day, and hour ranges can be determined according to the range of the span.

  • 'log' Logarithmic axis. Suitable for the logarithmic data.

xAxis3D.name: min
xAxis3D.desc:
The minimum value of axis.

It can be set to a special value 'dataMin' so that the minimum value on this axis is set to be the minimum label.

It will be automatically computed to make sure the axis tick is equally distributed when not set.

In the category axis, it can also be set as the ordinal number. For example, if a category axis has data: ['categoryA', 'categoryB', 'categoryC'], and the ordinal 2 represents 'categoryC'. Moreover, it can be set as a negative number, like -3.

xAxis3D.name: max
xAxis3D.desc:
The maximum value of the axis.

It can be set to a special value 'dataMax' so that the minimum value on this axis is set to be the maximum label.

It will be automatically computed to make sure the axis tick is equally distributed when not set.

In the category axis, it can also be set as the ordinal number. For example, if a category axis has data: ['categoryA', 'categoryB', 'categoryC'], and the ordinal 2 represents 'categoryC'. Moreover, it can be set as a negative number, like -3.

xAxis3D.name: scale
xAxis3D.desc:
It is available only in numerical axis, i.e., type: 'value'.

It specifies whether not to contain zero position of axis compulsively. When it is set to be true, the axis may not contain zero position, which is useful in the scatter chart for both value axes.

This configuration item is unavailable when the min and max are set.

xAxis3D.name: splitNumber
xAxis3D.desc:
The number of segments that the axis is split into. Note that this number serves only as a recommendation, and the true segments may be adjusted based on readability.

This is unavailable for the category axis.

xAxis3D.name: minInterval
xAxis3D.desc:
Minimum gap between split lines.

For example, it can be set to be 1 to make sure the axis label is shown as an integer.

{
    minInterval: 1
}

It is available only for axis of type 'value' or 'time'.

xAxis3D.name: interval
xAxis3D.desc:
Compulsively set segmentation interval for axis.

As splitNumber is a recommendation value, the calculated tick may not be the same as expected. In this case, interval should be used along with min and max to compulsively set tickings. But in most cases, we do not suggest using this, out automatic calculation is enough for most situations.

This is unavailable for category axis. Timestamp should be passed for type: 'time' axis. Logged value should be passed for type: 'log' axis.

xAxis3D.name: logBase
xAxis3D.desc: Base of logarithm, which is valid only for numeric axes with type: 'log'.

xAxis3D.name: data
xAxis3D.desc:
Category data, available in type: 'category' axis.

If type is specified as 'category', but axis.data is not specified, axis.data will be auto collected from series.data. It brings convenience, but we should notice that axis.data provides then value range of the 'category' axis. If it is auto collected from series.data, Only the values appearing in series.data can be collected. For example, if series.data is empty, nothing will be collected.

Example:

// Name list of all categories
data: ['Monday', 'Tuesday', 'Wednesday', 'Thursday', 'Friday', 'Saturday', 'Sunday']
// Each item could also be a specific configuration item.
// In this case, `value` is used as the category name.
data: [{
    value: 'Monday',
    // Highlight Monday
    textStyle: {
        fontSize: 20,
        color: 'red'
    }
}, 'Tuesday', 'Wednesday', 'Thursday', 'Friday', 'Saturday', 'Sunday']

xAxis3D.name: axisLine
xAxis3D.desc: Settings related to axis line.

xAxis3D.name: axisLabel
xAxis3D.desc: Settings related to axis label.

xAxis3D.name: axisTick
xAxis3D.desc: Settings related to axis tick.

xAxis3D.name: splitLine
xAxis3D.desc: Settings related to axis line.

xAxis3D.name: splitArea
xAxis3D.desc: Split area of axis in grid area.

xAxis3D.name: axisPointer
xAxis3D.desc: Configurations for axis pointer.

xAxis3D.nameTextStyle.name: color
xAxis3D.nameTextStyle.desc: Color of axis name uses axisLine.lineStyle.color by default.

xAxis3D.nameTextStyle.name: fontWeight
xAxis3D.nameTextStyle.desc:
The font thick weight of the text.

Optional:

  • 'bold'
  • 'bolder'
  • 'lighter'
  • 100 | 200 | 300 | 400...

xAxis3D.data.textStyle.name: fontWeight

The font thick weight of the text.

Optional:

  • 'bold'
  • 'bolder'
  • 'lighter'
  • 100 | 200 | 300 | 400...

The display interval of

xAxis3D.axisLine.name: interval
xAxis3D.axisLine.desc:
axis scale label is valid in the category axis.

By default, interval is automatically calculated to ensure a good display.

It can be set to 0 to force all labels to be displayed.

If the value is 1, it means "displays a label every other label". If the value is 2, it means "displays a label between two labels", and so on.

The interval data can be represented by a numerical value or by a callback function. The format of the callback function is as follows:

(index:number, value: string) => boolean

The first parameter is the index of the class, the second value is the name of the class, and if it is skipped, it returns false.

xAxis3D.axisLine.lineStyle.name: color
xAxis3D.axisLine.lineStyle.desc:
The color of the line.

In addition to color strings, RGBA values represented by arrays are supported, for example:

// pure white
[1, 1, 1, 1]

When using an array representation, each channel can set a value greater than 1 to represent the color value of HDR.

xAxis3D.axisLabel.name: show
xAxis3D.axisLabel.desc: Set this to be false to prevent the axis label from appearing.

xAxis3D.axisLabel.name: margin
xAxis3D.axisLabel.desc:
The margin between the axis label and the axis line.

Note： This distance is three-dimensional space, not screen space.

xAxis3D.axisLabel.name: interval
xAxis3D.axisLabel.desc:
axis scale label is valid in the category axis.

By default, interval is automatically calculated to ensure a good display.

It can be set to 0 to force all labels to be displayed.

If the value is 1, it means "displays a label every other label". If the value is 2, it means "displays a label between two labels", and so on.

The interval data can be represented by a numerical value or by a callback function. The format of the callback function is as follows:

(index:number, value: string) => boolean

The first parameter is the index of the class, the second value is the name of the class, and if it is skipped, it returns false.

xAxis3D.axisLabel.textStyle.name: color
xAxis3D.axisLabel.textStyle.desc:
Color of axis label is set to be axisLine.lineStyle.color by default. Callback function is supported, in the following format:

(val: string) => Color

Parameter is the text of label, and return value is the color. See the following example:

textStyle: {
    color: function (value, index) {
        return value >= 0 ? 'green' : 'red';
    }
}

xAxis3D.axisLabel.textStyle.name: fontWeight
xAxis3D.axisLabel.textStyle.desc:
The font thick weight of the text.

Optional:

  • 'normal'
  • 'bold'
  • 'bolder'
  • 'lighter'
  • 100 | 200 | 300 | 400...

xAxis3D.splitArea.areaStyle.name: color

xAxis3D.axisPointer.label.name: formatter
xAxis3D.axisPointer.label.desc:
The formatter of the label. . The first parameter to the function is the value of the current axis. The second parameter to the function is an array of values for all axes.

(value: number, valueAll: Array) => string

xAxis3D.axisPointer.label.name: margin

yAxis3D.name: show
yAxis3D.desc: Whether to display the y-axis.

yAxis3D.name: name
yAxis3D.desc: The name of the axis.

yAxis3D.name: grid3DIndex
yAxis3D.desc: The index of the grid3D component used by the axis. The default is to use the first grid3D component.

yAxis3D.name: nameTextStyle
yAxis3D.desc: Text style of axis name.

yAxis3D.name: nameGap
yAxis3D.desc: The gap between the axis name and axis line. Note the distance is in 3D space, not the screen pixel value.

yAxis3D.name: type
yAxis3D.desc:
The type of the axis.

Optional:

  • 'value' The value axis. Suitable for continuous data.

  • 'category' The category axis. Suitable for the discrete category data. For this type, the category data must be set through data.

  • 'time' The timeline. Suitable for the continuous timing data. The time axis has a time format compared to the value axis, and the scale calculation is also different. For example, the scale of the month, week, day, and hour ranges can be determined according to the range of the span.

  • 'log' Logarithmic axis. Suitable for the logarithmic data.

yAxis3D.name: min
yAxis3D.desc:
The minimum value of axis.

It can be set to a special value 'dataMin' so that the minimum value on this axis is set to be the minimum label.

It will be automatically computed to make sure the axis tick is equally distributed when not set.

In the category axis, it can also be set as the ordinal number. For example, if a category axis has data: ['categoryA', 'categoryB', 'categoryC'], and the ordinal 2 represents 'categoryC'. Moreover, it can be set as a negative number, like -3.

yAxis3D.name: max
yAxis3D.desc:
The maximum value of the axis.

It can be set to a special value 'dataMax' so that the minimum value on this axis is set to be the maximum label.

It will be automatically computed to make sure the axis tick is equally distributed when not set.

In the category axis, it can also be set as the ordinal number. For example, if a category axis has data: ['categoryA', 'categoryB', 'categoryC'], and the ordinal 2 represents 'categoryC'. Moreover, it can be set as a negative number, like -3.

yAxis3D.name: scale
yAxis3D.desc:
It is available only in numerical axis, i.e., type: 'value'.

It specifies whether not to contain zero position of axis compulsively. When it is set to be true, the axis may not contain zero position, which is useful in the scatter chart for both value axes.

This configuration item is unavailable when the min and max are set.

yAxis3D.name: splitNumber
yAxis3D.desc:
The number of segments that the axis is split into. Note that this number serves only as a recommendation, and the true segments may be adjusted based on readability.

This is unavailable for the category axis.

yAxis3D.name: minInterval
yAxis3D.desc:
Minimum gap between split lines.

For example, it can be set to be 1 to make sure the axis label is shown as an integer.

{
    minInterval: 1
}

It is available only for axis of type 'value' or 'time'.

yAxis3D.name: interval
yAxis3D.desc:
Compulsively set segmentation interval for axis.

As splitNumber is a recommendation value, the calculated tick may not be the same as expected. In this case, interval should be used along with min and max to compulsively set tickings. But in most cases, we do not suggest using this, out automatic calculation is enough for most situations.

This is unavailable for category axis. Timestamp should be passed for type: 'time' axis. Logged value should be passed for type: 'log' axis.

yAxis3D.name: logBase
yAxis3D.desc: Base of logarithm, which is valid only for numeric axes with type: 'log'.

yAxis3D.name: data
yAxis3D.desc:
Category data, available in type: 'category' axis.

If type is specified as 'category', but axis.data is not specified, axis.data will be auto collected from series.data. It brings convenience, but we should notice that axis.data provides then value range of the 'category' axis. If it is auto collected from series.data, Only the values appearing in series.data can be collected. For example, if series.data is empty, nothing will be collected.

Example:

// Name list of all categories
data: ['Monday', 'Tuesday', 'Wednesday', 'Thursday', 'Friday', 'Saturday', 'Sunday']
// Each item could also be a specific configuration item.
// In this case, `value` is used as the category name.
data: [{
    value: 'Monday',
    // Highlight Monday
    textStyle: {
        fontSize: 20,
        color: 'red'
    }
}, 'Tuesday', 'Wednesday', 'Thursday', 'Friday', 'Saturday', 'Sunday']

zAxis3D.axisTick.desc: Set this to be false to prevent the axis tick from showing.

zAxis3D.axisTick.name: interval
zAxis3D.axisTick.desc:
axis scale label is valid in the category axis. Defaults to the same as axisLabel.interval.

By default, interval is automatically calculated to ensure a good display.

It can be set to 0 to force all labels to be displayed.

If the value is 1, it means "displays a label every other label". If the value is 2, it means "displays a label between two labels", and so on.

The interval data can be represented by a numerical value or by a callback function. The format of the callback function is as follows:

(index:number, value: string) => boolean

The first parameter is the index of the class, the second value is the name of the class, and if it is skipped, it returns false.

zAxis3D.axisTick.lineStyle.name: color
zAxis3D.axisTick.lineStyle.desc: Color of axis label is set to be axisLine.lineStyle.color by default.

zAxis3D.axisTick.lineStyle.name: width
zAxis3D.axisTick.lineStyle.desc: The width of the line.

zAxis3D.splitLine.name: show
zAxis3D.splitLine.desc: Set this to be false to prevent the axis line from showing.

zAxis3D.splitLine.name: interval
zAxis3D.splitLine.desc:
axis scale label is valid in the category axis.

By default, interval is automatically calculated to ensure a good display.

It can be set to 0 to force all labels to be displayed.

If the value is 1, it means "displays a label every other label". If the value is 2, it means "displays a label between two labels", and so on.

The interval data can be represented by a numerical value or by a callback function. The format of the callback function is as follows:

(index:number, value: string) => boolean

The first parameter is the index of the class, the second value is the name of the class, and if it is skipped, it returns false.

zAxis3D.splitLine.lineStyle.name: color
zAxis3D.splitLine.lineStyle.desc:
The color of the line.

In addition to color strings, RGBA values represented by arrays are supported, for example:

// pure white
[1, 1, 1, 1]

When using an array representation, each channel can set a value greater than 1 to represent the color value of HDR.

zAxis3D.splitArea.name: show
zAxis3D.splitArea.desc: Set this to be true to show the splitArea.

zAxis3D.splitArea.name: interval
zAxis3D.splitArea.desc:
Axis splitArea is valid in the category axis. Defaults to the same as axisLabel.interval.

By default, interval is automatically calculated to ensure a good display.

It can be set to 0 to force all labels to be displayed.

If the value is 1, it means "displays a label every other label". If the value is 2, it means "displays a label between two labels", and so on.

The interval data can be represented by a numerical value or by a callback function. The format of the callback function is as follows:

(index:number, value: string) => boolean

The first parameter is the index of the class, the second value is the name of the class, and if it is skipped, it returns false.

zAxis3D.splitArea.areaStyle.name: color
zAxis3D.splitArea.areaStyle.desc: Color of the split area. The split area color could also be set in color array, which the split lines would take as their colors in turns. Dark and light colors in turns are used by default.

zAxis3D.axisPointer.name: show
zAxis3D.axisPointer.desc: Whether to display the axisPointer. Set this to be true to show the splitArea.

zAxis3D.axisPointer.lineStyle.name: color
zAxis3D.axisPointer.lineStyle.desc:
The color of the line.

In addition to color strings, RGBA values represented by arrays are supported, for example:

// pure white
[1, 1, 1, 1]

When using an array representation, each channel can set a value greater than 1 to represent the color value of HDR.

zAxis3D.axisPointer.label.name: show
zAxis3D.axisPointer.label.desc: Whether to display the label of axisPointer. Value axes are displayed by default, while category axes are not.

zAxis3D.axisPointer.label.name: formatter
zAxis3D.axisPointer.label.desc:
The formatter of the label. . The first parameter to the function is the value of the current axis. The second parameter to the function is an array of values for all axes.

(value: number, valueAll: Array) => string

zAxis3D.axisPointer.label.name: margin
zAxis3D.axisPointer.label.desc: Distance between label and axis. Like the scale label, this distance is a 3D space rather than a screen pixel.

zAxis3D.axisPointer.label.textStyle.name: fontWeight
zAxis3D.axisPointer.label.textStyle.desc:
The font thick weight of the text.

Optional:

  • 'normal'
  • 'bold'
  • 'bolder'
  • 'lighter'
  • 100 | 200 | 300 | 400...

series.scatter3D.name: name
series.scatter3D.desc: Series name used for displaying in tooltip and filtering with legend, or updating data and configuration with setOption.

series.scatter3D.name: coordinateSystem
series.scatter3D.desc:
The coordinate used in the series, whose options are:

  • 'cartesian3D'

    Use a 3D rectangular coordinate (also known as Cartesian coordinate), with xAxisIndex and yAxisIndex to assign the corresponding axis component.

  • 'geo3D' Use 3D geographic coordinate, with geoIndex to assign the corresponding 3D geographic coordinate components.

  • 'globe'

    Use 3D globe coordinate, with globeIndex to assign the corresponding 3D globe coordinate components.

series.scatter3D.name: grid3DIndex
series.scatter3D.desc: Use the index of the grid3D component. The first grid3D component is used by default.

series.scatter3D.name: geo3DIndex
series.scatter3D.desc: The index of the geo3D component used by the axis.The first grid3D component is used by default.

series.scatter3D.name: globeIndex
series.scatter3D.desc: The index of the globe component used by the axis.The first globe component is used by default.

series.scatter3D.name: symbol
series.scatter3D.desc:
The shape of the scatter. The default is a circle.

Icon types provided by ECharts includes 'circle', 'rect', 'roundRect', 'triangle', 'diamond', 'pin', 'arrow', 'none'

Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via 'path://' in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to SVG PathData for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe

series.scatter3D.name: symbolSize
series.scatter3D.desc:
symbol size. It can be set to single numbers like 10, or use an array to represent width and height. For example, [20, 10] means symbol width is 20, and height is10.

If size of symbols needs to be different, you can set with callback function in the following format:

(value: Array|number, params: Object) => number|Array

The first parameter value is the value in data, and the second parameter params is the rest parameters of data item.

series.scatter3D.name: itemStyle
series.scatter3D.desc: Sets the style of scatter such as colors, strokes, etc.

series.scatter3D.name: data
series.scatter3D.desc:
The data array of scatter3D. Each item in the array is a piece of data. Usually, this data stores each attribute/dimension of the data in an array. As Follows:

data: [
    [[12, 14, 10], [34, 50, 15], [56, 30, 20], [10, 15, 12], [23, 10, 14]]
]

For each item in the array：

  1. In grid3D ,the first three values of each item arex, y, z.
  2. In geo3D and globe ,the first two values of each item are longitude lng, latitude lat,

In addition to the default values for the coordinates, each item can be added with any number of values to visualMap the component for any other graphical property, such as color, etc.

More likely, we need to assign name to each data item, in which case each item should be an object:

[{
    // name of date item
    name: 'data1',
    // value of date item is 8
    value: [12, 14, 10]
}, {
    name: 'data2',
    value: 20
}]

Each data item can be further customized:

[{
    name: 'data1',
    value: [12, 14, 10]
}, {
    // name of data item
    name: 'data2',
    value : [34, 50, 15],
    // user-defined special itemStyle that only useful for this data item
    itemStyle:{}
}]

series.scatter3D.name: blendMode
series.scatter3D.desc:
Sets the type of compositing operation to apply when drawing a new shape.

Currently supporting 'source-over', 'lighter'. The default is 'source-over' mode is blended by alpha. The 'lighter' is overlap mode. In this mode, the area where the number of graphics is concentrated can be highlighted by the overlap.

series.scatter3D.name: zlevel
series.scatter3D.desc:
The layer in which the component is located.

zlevel is used to make layers with Canvas. Graphical elements with different zlevel values will be placed in different Canvases, which is a common optimization technique. We can put those frequently changed elements (like those with animations) to a separate zlevel. Notice that too many Canvases will increase memory cost, and should be used carefully on mobile phones to avoid the crash.

Canvases with bigger zlevel will be placed on Canvases with smaller zlevel.

Note: The layers of the components in echarts-gl need to be separated from the layers of the components in echarts. The same zlevel cannot be used for both WebGL and Canvas drawing at the same time.

series.scatter3D.name: silent
series.scatter3D.desc: Whether the graph doesn`t respond and triggers a mouse event. The default is false, which is to respond to and trigger mouse events.

series.scatter3D.name: animationDurationUpdate
series.scatter3D.desc: The duration time for update the transition animation.

series.scatter3D.name: animationEasingUpdate
series.scatter3D.desc: The easing effect for update transition animation.

series.scatter3D.itemStyle.name: color
series.scatter3D.itemStyle.desc:
The color of the graphic. 

// pure white
[1, 1, 1, 1]

When using an array representation, each channel can set a value greater than 1 to represent the color value of HDR.

series.scatter3D.label.name: distance
series.scatter3D.label.desc:
Distance to the host graphic element.

The distance from the label to the graphic. In a 3D Scatter, this distance is the pixel value of the screen space. In other figures, this distance is the relative 3D distance.

series.scatter3D.label.name: formatter
series.scatter3D.label.desc:
The formatter of the label content, which supports the string template and the callback function. In either form, \n is supported to represent a new line.

String template:

The model variation includes:

  • {a}: series name.
  • {b}: the name of a data item.
  • {c}: the value of a data item.

Example:

formatter: '{b}: {c}'

Callback function: Callback function is in form of:

(params: Object|Array) => string

The params is the single data set needed by formatter, which is formed as:

{
    componentType: 'series',
    // Series type
    seriesType: string,
    // Series index in option.series
    seriesIndex: number,
    // Series name
    seriesName: string,
    // Data name, or category name
    name: string,
    // Data index in input data array
    dataIndex: number,
    // Original data as input
    data: Object,
    // Value of data. In most series it is the same as data.
    // But in some series it is some part of the data (e.g., in map, radar)
    value: number|Array|Object,
    // encoding info of coordinate system
    // Key: coord, like ('x' 'y' 'radius' 'angle')
    // value: Must be an array, not null/undefined. Contain dimension indices, like:
    // {
    //     x: [2] // values on dimension index 2 are mapped to x axis.
    //     y: [0] // values on dimension index 0 are mapped to y axis.
    // }
    encode: Object,
    // dimension names list
    dimensionNames: Array<String>,
    // data dimension index, for example 0 or 1 or 2 ...
    // Only work in `radar` series.
    dimensionIndex: number,
    // Color of data
    color: string,

}

Note: the usage of encode and dimensionNames can be:

If data is:

dataset: {
    source: [
        ['Matcha Latte', 43.3, 85.8, 93.7],
        ['Milk Tea', 83.1, 73.4, 55.1],
        ['Cheese Cocoa', 86.4, 65.2, 82.5],
        ['Walnut Brownie', 72.4, 53.9, 39.1]
    ]
}

We can get values that corresponding to y axis by:

params.value[params.encode.y[0]]

If data is:

dataset: {
    dimensions: ['product', '2015', '2016', '2017'],
    source: [
        {product: 'Matcha Latte', '2015': 43.3, '2016': 85.8, '2017': 93.7},
        {product: 'Milk Tea', '2015': 83.1, '2016': 73.4, '2017': 55.1},
        {product: 'Cheese Cocoa', '2015': 86.4, '2016': 65.2, '2017': 82.5},
        {product: 'Walnut Brownie', '2015': 72.4, '2016': 53.9, '2017': 39.1}
    ]
}

We can get values that corresponding to y axis by:

params.value[params.dimensionNames[params.encode.y[0]]]

series.scatter3D.label.textStyle.name: fontWeight
series.scatter3D.label.textStyle.desc:
The font thick weight of the text.

Optional:

  • 'normal'
  • 'bold'
  • 'bolder'
  • 'lighter'
  • 100 | 200 | 300 | 400...

series.scatter3D.emphasis.itemStyle.name: color

series.name: scatter3D
series.desc:
3D scatter chart. It can be used to display data in grid3D, geo3D, globe using attributes such as size、color and so on.

This example is a 3D simplex noise drawn with a bubble chart.

series.name: bar3D
series.desc:
3D bar. It can be used to display data in grid3D, geo3D, globe using attributes such as size 、color and so on.

The figure below shows the population density data of the world through a 3D bar chart on [geo3D] (~geo3D).

series.name: line3D
series.desc: 3D Line. Can be used for [grid3D] (~grid3D)

series.name: lines3D
series.desc:
3D lines. Like the 2D [lines] (https://echarts.apache.org/zh/option.html#series-line), it is used to represent the line data from the start point to the end point. More is used in geographic visualization.

Below is an example of a visual airplane flight using lines3D on globe.

series.name: map3D
series.desc:
3D map

3D maps are mainly used for visualizing geographic area data. With the [visualMap] (http://echarts.baidu.com/option.html#visualMap) component, it can be used to display data such as population distribution density in different regions.

Compared to 2D maps, 3D maps can set different heights for each area. This height can be used to display data and to display the height of the building in the building data.

series.name: surface
series.desc:
Surface. Support to drawn the [Parameter surface] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parametric_surface) by parametric.

The figure below is a parametric surface similar to a metal part configured as a metal material.

series.name: polygons3D
series.desc: polygons3D is used to visualize polygon data with high information on the map, which is often used for drawing of buildings. The picture below shows the nearly 50w number of New York buildings drawn with polygons3D.

series.name: scatterGL
series.desc:
A 2D scatter/bubble plot drawn using WebGL.

It is used in the same way as scatter.

series.name: graphGL
series.desc: Uses WebGL to drawn the relational chart, support the layout and rendering of large-scale network/relational data.

series.name: flowGL
series.desc:
The flowGL component visualizes the traces of the vector field through the particle effects implemented by WebGL.

The figure below shows the effect of the global wind field visualized by flowGL.

series.bar3D.name: name
series.bar3D.desc: Series name used for displaying in tooltip and filtering with legend, or updating data and configuration with setOption.

series.bar3D.name: coordinateSystem
series.bar3D.desc:
The coordinate used in the series, whose options are:

  • 'cartesian3D'

    Use a 3D rectangular coordinate (also known as Cartesian coordinate), with xAxisIndex and yAxisIndex to assign the corresponding axis component.

  • 'geo3D' Use 3D geographic coordinate, with geoIndex to assign the corresponding 3D geographic coordinate components.

  • 'globe'

    Use 3D globe coordinate, with globeIndex to assign the corresponding 3D globe coordinate components.

series.bar3D.name: grid3DIndex
series.bar3D.desc: Use the index of the grid3D component. The first grid3D component is used by default.

series.bar3D.name: geo3DIndex
series.bar3D.desc: The index of the geo3D component used by the axis.The first grid3D component is used by default.

series.bar3D.name: globeIndex
series.bar3D.desc: The index of the globe component used by the axis.The first globe component is used by default.

series.bar3D.name: bevelSize
series.bar3D.desc:
The size of the bevel. Support for setting values from 0 to 1. The default is 0, which means there is no bevel.

Below are the differences between beveling and no beveling.

series.bar3D.name: bevelSmoothness
series.bar3D.desc: The smoothness of the bevel, the larger the value, the smoother.

series.bar3D.name: stack
series.bar3D.desc: Stacking of bar chart. On the same category axis, the series with the same stack name would be put on top of each other. Note that the data items that need to be stack in different series must have the same index in the array.

series.bar3D.name: minHeight
series.bar3D.desc: The minimum width of the bar.

series.bar3D.name: itemStyle
series.bar3D.desc: The style of the bar, including color and opacity.

series.bar3D.name: label
series.bar3D.desc: Configure the label of the bar.

series.bar3D.name: emphasis
series.bar3D.desc: Configure labels and styles for bar highlighting.

series.bar3D.name: data
series.bar3D.desc:
A data array of 3D bar. Each item of the array is a piece of data. Usually this data is an array to store each attribute/dimension of the data. For example below:

data: [
    [[12, 14, 10], [34, 50, 15], [56, 30, 20], [10, 15, 12], [23, 10, 14]]
]

For each item in the array:

  1. In [grid3D] (~grid3D), the first three values of each item are x, y, z.
  2. In geo3D and globe, the first two values of each item are longitude lng, latitude lat, and the third value indicates the size of the value, such as the number of people. This value will be mapped to the range of minHeight ~ maxHeight.

In addition to the three values used by default for the coordinate system, each item can be added with any number of values for mapping the visualMap component to other graphical properties such as color.

More likely, we need to assign name to each data item, in which case each item should be an object:

[{
    // name of date item
    name: 'data1',
    // value of date item is 8
    value: [12, 14, 10]
}, {
    name: 'data2',
    value: 20
}]

Each data item can be further customized:

[{
    name: 'data1',
    value: [12, 14, 10]
}, {
    // name of data item
    name: 'data2',
    value : [34, 50, 15],
    // user-defined special itemStyle that only useful for this data item
    itemStyle:{}
}]

series.bar3D.name: shading
series.bar3D.desc:
The coloring effect of 3D graphics in 3D Bar. The following three coloring methods are supported in echarts-gl:

  • 'color' Only display colors, not affected by other factors such as lighting.

  • 'lambert' Through the classic [lambert] coloring, can express the light and dark that the light shows.

  • 'realistic' Realistic rendering, combined with light.ambientCubemap and postEffect, can improve the quality and texture of the display. [Physical Based Rendering (PBR)] (https://www.marmoset.co/posts/physically-based-rendering-and-you-can-too/) is used in ECharts GL to represent realistic materials.

series.bar3D.name: realisticMaterial
series.bar3D.desc: The configuration item of the realistic material is valid when shading is 'realistic'.

series.bar3D.name: lambertMaterial
series.bar3D.desc: The configuration item of the lambert material is valid when shading is 'lambert'.

series.bar3D.name: colorMaterial
series.bar3D.desc: The color material related configuration item is valid when shading is 'color'.

series.bar3D.desc:
The layer in which the component is located.

zlevel is used to make layers with Canvas. Graphical elements with different zlevel values will be placed in different Canvases, which is a common optimization technique. We can put those frequently changed elements (like those with animations) to a separate zlevel. Notice that too many Canvases will increase memory cost, and should be used carefully on mobile phones to avoid the crash.

Canvases with bigger zlevel will be placed on Canvases with smaller zlevel.

Note: The layers of the components in echarts-gl need to be separated from the layers of the components in echarts. The same zlevel cannot be used for both WebGL and Canvas drawing at the same time.

series.bar3D.name: animation
series.bar3D.desc: Whether to enable animation.

series.bar3D.name: animationDurationUpdate
series.bar3D.desc: The duration time for update the transition animation.

series.bar3D.name: animationEasingUpdate

}

Note: the usage of encode and dimensionNames can be:

If data is:

dataset: {

        ['Walnut Brownie', 72.4, 53.9, 39.1]
    ]
}

We can get values that corresponding to y axis by:

params.value[params.encode.y[0]]

If data is:

dataset: {
    dimensions: ['product', '2015', '2016', '2017'],
    source: [
        {product: 'Matcha Latte', '2015': 43.3, '2016': 85.8, '2017': 93.7},
        {product: 'Milk Tea', '2015': 83.1, '2016': 73.4, '2017': 55.1},
        {product: 'Cheese Cocoa', '2015': 86.4, '2016': 65.2, '2017': 82.5},
        {product: 'Walnut Brownie', '2015': 72.4, '2016': 53.9, '2017': 39.1}
    ]
}

We can get values that corresponding to y axis by:

params.value[params.dimensionNames[params.encode.y[0]]]

series.bar3D.emphasis.label.name: distance
series.bar3D.emphasis.label.desc:
Distance to the host graphic element.

The distance from the label to the graphic. In a 3D Scatter, this distance is the pixel value of the screen space. In other figures, this distance is the relative 3D distance.

series.bar3D.emphasis.label.name: formatter
series.bar3D.emphasis.label.desc:
The formatter of the label content, which supports the string template and the callback function. In either form, \n is supported to represent a new line.

String template:

The model variation includes:

  • {a}: series name.
  • {b}: the name of a data item.
  • {c}: the value of a data item.

Example:

formatter: '{b}: {c}'

Callback function: Callback function is in form of:

(params: Object|Array) => string

The params is the single data set needed by formatter, which is formed as:

{
    componentType: 'series',
    // Series type
    seriesType: string,
    // Series index in option.series
    seriesIndex: number,
    // Series name
    seriesName: string,
    // Data name, or category name
    name: string,
    // Data index in input data array
    dataIndex: number,
    // Original data as input
    data: Object,
    // Value of data. In most series it is the same as data.
    // But in some series it is some part of the data (e.g., in map, radar)
    value: number|Array|Object,
    // encoding info of coordinate system
    // Key: coord, like ('x' 'y' 'radius' 'angle')
    // value: Must be an array, not null/undefined. Contain dimension indices, like:
    // {
    //     x: [2] // values on dimension index 2 are mapped to x axis.
    //     y: [0] // values on dimension index 0 are mapped to y axis.
    // }
    encode: Object,
    // dimension names list
    dimensionNames: Array<String>,
    // data dimension index, for example 0 or 1 or 2 ...
    // Only work in `radar` series.
    dimensionIndex: number,
    // Color of data
    color: string,

}

Note: the usage of encode and dimensionNames can be:

If data is:

dataset: {
    source: [
        ['Matcha Latte', 43.3, 85.8, 93.7],
        ['Milk Tea', 83.1, 73.4, 55.1],
        ['Cheese Cocoa', 86.4, 65.2, 82.5],
        ['Walnut Brownie', 72.4, 53.9, 39.1]
    ]
}

We can get values that corresponding to y axis by:

params.value[params.encode.y[0]]

If data is:

dataset: {
    dimensions: ['product', '2015', '2016', '2017'],
    source: [
        {product: 'Matcha Latte', '2015': 43.3, '2016': 85.8, '2017': 93.7},
        {product: 'Milk Tea', '2015': 83.1, '2016': 73.4, '2017': 55.1},
        {product: 'Cheese Cocoa', '2015': 86.4, '2016': 65.2, '2017': 82.5},
        {product: 'Walnut Brownie', '2015': 72.4, '2016': 53.9, '2017': 39.1}
    ]
}

We can get values that corresponding to y axis by:

params.value[params.dimensionNames[params.encode.y[0]]]
